person.name: Ἀγήνωρ

person.name: Ἀγησανδρίδας
person.note: Poralla 5; Thucydides VIII 91.2, 94-5a, 107b; Diodorus XIII 41c; Xenophon Hellenica I 1.1d, 3.17e
In 411 he defeated the Athenian fleet near Oropus and caused Euboea to defect.a

After the battle of Cynossema he went to the Hellespont under the orders of the nauarch Mindares, but was shipwrecked near Athos.bc With the ships that were saved he defeated the Athenian Thymochares.d

person.name: Ἀγήσανδρος
person.note: In 431 BC, as part of the third Spartan embassy, he presented the
ultimatum to Athens before the outbreak of the Peloponnesian War.

person.note: Poralla 8 (cf. Appendix Agiden); Herodotus VII 204; Pausanias III 2.4
According to the ancient chronographers he ruled for 44 years, but
Pausanias assigns him only a short reign.

person.name: Ἀγησίλαος II
person.note: Poralla 9; Diodorus 14.80a, 15.31-34b, 82.6-83.5c, 92-3d; Nepos Agesilaus (8e), Timotheus 1.3f, Conon 2, Chabrias 1,2, de regibus 1; Pausanias III 8.8ffg, 9.1-5h, IV 17.5, VI 4.9, 15.7, VIII 6.2, IX 13.2, 14.5; Plutarch Agesilaus (1i, 3j, 6k, 7-13l, 17-19m, 20n, 21o, 22p, 27-8q, 31-33r, 34s, 36-40t), Lysander 22u, 24v, Lycurgus 30.5, Artaxerxes 22.4-7, Moralia (de audiendis poetis) 31c, (de adulatore et amico) 52f, 55d, (de profectibus in virtute) 78d, 81a, 85b, (regum et imperatorum apophthegmata) 189e, (apophthegmata Laconica) 208b-215a, 229f, (parallela Graeca et Romana) 308b, (de Alexandri fortuna) 343a, (de Pythiae oraculis) 399b, (de fraterno amore) 482d, (de vitioso pudore) 533e-534b, (de laude ipsius) 545a, (de genio Socratis) 577e, 578f, (quaestionum convivalium II 10.2) 644b, (an seni sit gerenda res puiblica) 784ef, 790b, (praecepta gerendae reipublicae) 805e, 807e, 809a/b, (non posse suaviter vivi secundum Epicurum) 1099b; Hellenica Oxyrhyncus 11.2-5, 12.1-4, 13.1, 21.1-4, 22.2,4w; Xenophon Agesilaus (1.25-35x; 2.17y, 21z, 26-7A, 9.6B); Hellenica C III 3-4 passim; IV-VI passim, VII 5.9, 10; Aristotle Politica 1306b35; SEG XI 457 (father?); Libanius declamationes XXIV 2 (mel): 6; Isocrates epistulae IX 11-14, orationes IV 144, 153, V 62, 86, 87; Athenaeus IV 144b, IX 384a, XII 511c, 550e, XIII 609b, XIV 613c, 616d, 657b; Josephus Bellum Judaicum II 359; Diogenes Laertius II 51, 52, 57, VI 39, VIII 87; Die Inschriften von Ephesos (der Österreichischen Akademie der Wissenschaften) II 133
Son of King Archidamos II and Eupolia
Half-brother of King Agis II and Teleutias
Agesilaos was born in 444/3 and about 402 married Kleora (cf. Aristomenidas) who bore him three children, Archidamos, Eupolia, and Prolyta.mC
When, after the death of Agis II in the summer of 399, Agis’ son Leotychidas was disqualified, Agesilaos—particularly through the influence of his boyhood friend Lysander—received the throne.Cujg
Likewise, through the efforts of Lysander was Agesilaos appointed the commander in the war against Persia. He sailed in the spring of 396 from Aulis to Ephesus.kCh
He conducted the war in Asia Minor until the summer of 394, when he was recalled because of political developments in Greece.Cxwlva
In thirty days he marched to Boeotia, where he established a camp at Chaeroneia on the 25th or 26th of August 394 and soon thereafter defeated the enemies of Sparta in the battle of Coronea.Cm
To heal the wound that he had received in the battle he took himself to Delphi and from there travelled home on a ship.Cx
In 391 he laid waste to Argos and continued on to Corinth where he had the long walls of Lechaeum torn down.Cy
In the summer of the next year <390> he was active at the IsthmusCop. There he fought on behalf of the Achaeans against the Acarnanians.Cp
At the peace conference in Sparta in 387/6 he forced through the recognition of the King’s Peace on the part of the Thebans and the dissolution of the just founded city Corinth-Argos.Cz
In the fall of 381 he struck against Phlius, which he took after a siege of twenty months.C

In similar fashion he participated in the great struggle between Thebes and Sparta. He undertook two operations to Boeotia in 378/7. A wound, which he received on the march back, kept him from the theater of war for a long time,Cb so he acted all the more energetically against Thebes in 371 at the congress at Sparta, when he excluded the Thebans from the common peace.Cq

After the catastrophe at Leuctra he campaigned with the full army against Mantinea, but had to withdraw to Sparta at the approach of the Thebans.C By his careful handling he saved the country from the invasion of Epaminondas in the winter of 370/69.r
Around 364 he travelled to Asia to earn money for Sparta and fought there together with the Athenian Timotheos for the interests of Ariobarzanes.Af
In 362 we find the king back in Greece, where shortly before the battle of Mantinea he saved Sparta a second time from a Theban invasion.Csc

In 361 he went to Egypt to enter the service of Tachos, to earn money for Sparta as the leader of a mercenary band. When he was demoted by Tachos he went over to Nectanebo and did important service for him. Therefore, when he prepared his return home, he was loaded with rich gifts. He never reached his homeland, but died in the winter of 360/59 between Egypt and Cyrene in the “harbor of Menelaos.” His body was brought back to Sparta.tde

person.name: Ἀγησίπολις I
person.note: Poralla 14; Diodorus XIV 89a, XV 22,2, 23,2b; Pausanias III 5.7c, VIII 8.7-9(f); Xenophon Hellenica IV 2.9d, 7.2-7e; V 2.3-7f, 3.8-9, 18-9g (Agesipolis and Agesilaus have been confused in Suidas s. v. Ἆγις and Diodorus XIV 97.5.)
When his father went into exile after the battle of Haliartos in 395, Agesipolis ascended the throneac. Since he was still a minor, he had a regent, Aristodemusd.

In 388/7 he led a successful campaign against the Argivese. In 385/4 he forced Mantinea to disband the league it had formedf. In the year 381 he invaded Chalcidice with a great army, but died shortly after the capture of Torone in Summer 380.
His body was brought to Spartabg.

person.name: Ἀγησίπολις II
person.note: After the death of his father in 371 Agesipolis succeeded to the throne, but he died after about a one-year reign and left no childrenabc.

person.name: Ἀγησίπολις (1)
person.note: Son of Kleombrotos (1) II and Chilonis (2)
He was young enough in 241 BC to be carried by a parent. He died before 219 BC.

person.name: Ἀγησίπολις (2) III
person.note: He was appointed king as a child after the death of Kleomenes (1) III,
219 BCab His uncle, Kleomenes (2), was regenta. He was expelled by Lykourgos (1)c. As an envoy to Rome, ca. 184 BC, he was killed by piratesb.

person.name: Ἀγησιππία (1)

person.name: [hA]γηḣιππία (2)

person.name: Ἀγησιππίδας
person.note: Commandant in Heraclea. In the summer of 419 he was sent back to

In the following winter he led reinforcements to the aid of the
Epidaurians who were hard pressed by the Argives.

person.name: Ἀγητορίδας (1)
person.note: A Spartiate who was sent by Agesilaos II to Memphis during the time when Plato was travelling in Egypt. We do not have an exact date for Plato’s Egyptian stay. Plato left Athens after the death of Socrates and travelled through the Peloponnesus, to Egypt and Cyrene. In 388 he had already visited Syracuse again. The trip of Agetoridas then, if it is at all historical, must fall in the period 399-388.

person.name: Ἀγιάδας (5)
person.note: IG V 1. 60 (restored from AIΓIAΛOΥ in an inscription <or transcription> filled with errors)

person.name: Ἁγίας
person.note: Poralla 21; Herodotus IX 33 (the name is known in the Ionian form:
Brother of the famous Elean seer Tisamenos.
Along with his brother he received Spartan citizenship shortly before the battle of Marathon.

person.name: Ἁγίας
person.note: Poralla 22; Pausanias III 11. 5-6, X 9.7 (where his name is written Ἄβας)
He belonged to the Elean family of seers which had been given citizenship in Sparta around 480. He took part in the battle of Aegospotami. (cf. Τισαμενός stemma)

person.name: Ἁγίας
person.note: Prostates of the naopoioi in the year of the Delphian archon Theucharis, Spring 354

person.name: Ἁ[γία]ς
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Kallikrates (33)

person.name: Ἀγιᾶτις
person.note: Wife of Agis (1) IV and mother of a son by him
Wife of Kleomenes (1) III and mother of at least two sons by him

She was a wealthy woman. After the death of Agis IV, Leonidas (1) II forced her to marry his son, Kleomenes, so that her wealth would not pass to another. She was supposed to have encouraged Kleomenes in his reforms.

person.name: Ἀγιδώ
person.note: Poralla 24; D. L. Page, Alcman, the Partheneion, Oxford. 1951)

person.name: Αὐρηλία Ἄγιον
person.note: Mother of M. Aurelius Kleonymos (3) ho kai Hymnos
She paid for a memorial to her son.
(Spawforth ABSA 79, 280, mother of the honorand, Sex. Pompeius Gorgippos, not of Kleonymos)

person.name: Ἄγιππος (1a)
person.note: Nomophylax in the year of M. Ulpius Sosikrat[es] (10), A.D. 111/2 or 112/3

person.name: Ἄγιππος (1b)
person.note: Pr(esbys) of ephors in the year of .... Aristokrates (13)b, AD 166/7 or later

person.name: Ἄγιππος (2)
person.note: Name in a catalogue from Oetylus

person.name: Ἆγις I
person.note: Poralla 25; Herodotus I 65a, VII 204b; Strabo VIII 365c; Pausanias III 16.9d
Father of Echestratos and, according to one version, of the lawgiver Lycurgusab.
He was the eponymous king of the house of the Agids—obviously a mythical personab.
During his reign (1061-1030/29) the helots were subjugatedc. He is also made the ultimate ancestor of the mythical Amphiklesd.

person.name: Ἆγις II
person.note: Poralla 26; Thucydides III 89a, IV 2. 6b, V 19, 24c, 54d, 57-60 & 63-75e, 83f, VII 19 & 27g, VIII 3h, 5-11 & 70-71i; Plutarch Agesilaus 1. 3j; Diodorus XI 48k, XII 35.4l, 78-79m, XIII 107n; Xenophon Hellenica I 1.33-35o, II 2. 7-13p, II 3.3q, III 2.22-29 & 3.1r; Pausanias III 8.3-5s, VI 2.3t; IDelos 87 (IG V 1. 1564); Justin V 2.5; Nepos Agesilaus 1; Athenaeus XII 535b, 543b
King from the house of the Eurypontids

After the death of Archidamos Agis assumed the throne in 427/6k. In the years 426 and 425 he twice led the army into Attica.ab With his fellow king Pleistoanax in 421 he underwrote the peace of Nicias and the alliance with Athens.c

In 419 he marched with the assembled army to Leuctra, but turned back to Sparta without accomplishing anything.d In the next summer he campaigned twice against the Argives and besieged them because of their alliance with Mantineaem. In a third campaign at the beginning of the winter of 417 he caused the newly built walls of Argos to be torn downf.

In spring 413 Agis invaded Attica and seized Decelea, where he remained as commanderg. From here he undertook in the following winter a campaign against the Oitaians and the Achaeans living in Phthiotis, to reestablish the influence of the Spartans on the Malean Gulfh. From Decelea Agis supported all rebellions against Athens in Asia Minor and along the Hellespont and tried several times to take the cityio. He did not take part in the siege of Athens in 405/4nq, although he did offer his good ofices to the Atheniansp.
After the fall of Athens he led a long campaign against Elist and visited Delphi. On his return trip he fell sick and died soon after his arrival in Sparta, probably in the summer of 399lrs.

person.name: Ἆγις III
person.note: Poralla 27; Plutarch Agis 3a; Pausanias III 10.5b; Arrian Anabasis II 13.6c; Diodorus XVI 88.4d, XVII 48.1-2e, 62.6-63.4f; Curtius VI 1g

He succeeded his father in 338 and ruled for nine yearsd. In 333, as leader of the opposition to Alexander the Great, Agis travelled to Siphnos to meet Pharnabazos and Autophradates, the commanders of the Persian fleet; he obtained money and troops from them. Then he travelled to Halicarnassos where he led some of the survivors of the Greek mercenaries from the battle of Issos to Cretece. After he returned to Sparta he besieged Megalopolis, but in a battle fought there against Antipater, he was killed (in 331 or 330)fg.

person.name: Ἆγις
person.note: He and his brothers (Eupylidas, Chairis, Lykos, Alexon, Eraton, and Gylippos) fell at Messene sometime after 369.

person.name: Ἆγις, Poralla 28a; Herodotus VI 65, cf. Ἀγησίλαος (Poralla 10)
Ἆγις, Poralla 28b; Suidas s. v., cf. Ἀγησίπολις I
Ἆγις (1) IV
person.note: Plutarch Agis passim, Cleomenes 1-3, Agesilaus 40.5; comparatio Agis Cleomenes Ti. Gracchus C. Gracchus, Aratus 31.1; Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica) 216d; Lamprias catalogue Number 9; Cicero de officiis II 80; Pausanias II 8.5; III 10.5; VI 2.4; VII 7.3; VIII 8.11, 10.5-8, 27.13-14, 36.6 (Pausanias confuses Agis IV and Archidamos IV); Prometheus VII 1981, pp. 35-42: Agis became king as a child with Agesilaos as his regent.
Son of Eudamidas (2) II and Agesistrata
He was the first king of Sparta to attempt to recover her military strength through an increase in the number of citizen-soldiers by cancellation of debt, distribution of land, and enfranchisement.
He was opposed by the wealthy and by Leonidas (1) II, the Agiad king, though a large minority of the fully enfranchised citizen body supported Agis.
With the help of his advisers and supporters, Lysandros (1), Mandrokleidas, and Agesilaos (2), he expelled Leonidas, brought Kleombrotos (1) II to the throne, and passed a bill cancelling debt.

He led an army to aid the Achaean League against the Aetolians, but no engagement was fought. In his absence his opponents gained the upper hand. (Pausanias confuses the actions of the Aetolians and the Spartans under Agis in his reading of Plutarch’s life of Aratus.)
Leonidas II returned from exile and forced Agis to seek sanctuary. Agis was betrayed, tried by the ephors, and executed.

person.name: Γά(ιος) Πομπώνιος Ἆγις (2)
person.note: First cousin of C. Pompo(nius) Alkastos (3)c

Subject of an honorary decree for his exercise of the office of gymnasiarchc; nomophy(lax)b; agonothetes and gra(mmato)phy(lax) of the Caesarian and Eurycleian games in the year of Agetoridas (3)b, AD 165/6 or later

person.name: Ἆγις (4)
person.note: Damion (3) kas(en) to him in the year of Lakon (3)b

person.name: Ἆγις (5)
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristokratidas (1)

person.name: Ἀγιτέλης
person.note: Koakter of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristomachos (3)b; sin pheron (bearer of the cult statue) of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Kallikrates (33)a

Seitones in the year of Dex[ima]chos (7) ho kai Nikokratesc, AD 86/7
Gerousias in the year of Pratonikos (20)c, AD 107/8
Ephor in the year of Damonikidas (6)c, AD 109/10
Tamias in the year of Polyeuktos (5)c, AD 110/1
Gerousias for the second time in the year of Aristokles (13)c, AD 111/2 or 112/3
Presbys of nomophylakes in the year of Antipatros (1)cd, AD 113/4 or 114/5
Gerousias for the third time in the year of Pius (2)bc, AD 115/6
Gerousias for the fourth time in the year of Aristoboulos (1)ac, AD 129/30
Pr(esbys) of bideoi in the year of Onasikleidas (1)c, AD 138/9-141
Gerousias for the fifth time in the year of Eudamos (6)c, AD 139/40-ca. 142

person.name: Γά(ιος) Ἰού[λ(ιος)] Ἁγίων (2)
person.note: [Synarch of the] pat[r]o[nomia] (in the year of) C. Ju[lius — ] (9)

person.name: Ἁγίων (4)
person.note: SEG XI 585; Steinhauer, BSA 93, pp. 427-447, #2, plate 71b

person.name: Ἁγνή
person.note: Mother of Faustus, two more sons, and a daughter
She survived Faustus, who died in his forties

person.name: ΑΓΡΙ or ΑΠΡ
person.note: Name on a coin—perhaps the mint official but more likely the holder of
the eponymous office, at this date probably the eponymous patronomos

person.name: [Ἀγρ]ίππας, IG V 1. 175, error for ἀλείπτας, cf. SEG XI 633
Ἀγύλαιος
person.note: Ephor who survived an attack of the supporters of Kleomenes (1) III by simulating death and taking sanctuary in the temple of Phobos

person.name: Ἀγχίβιος
person.note: Name on an inscription found in Geronthrai

person.name: Ἀγχιθέα, Poralla 29a; Suidas s. v. Παυσανίας, cf. Ἀλκαθόα
Ἀγχίμολος
person.note: Poralla 30; Herodotus V 63 (Ἀγχιμόλιος); Aristotle Athenaion Politeia 19, Scholia to Aristophanes Lysistrata 1153
Campaigned by ship against the Peisistratids in Athens in 511/10 and was defeated and killed by Hippias and the Thessalian cavalry. His grave memorial was located in the Attic deme Alopeke.

person.name: Ἀδαῖος, Poralla 30a; Plutarch Agesilaus 13, cf. Ἰδαῖος
Ἀδείμαντος
person.note: Polybius IV 22.7-23.9; J. Toepffer, “Adeimantos (7),” RE, I Halbband (Stuttgart, 1893), 355
Ephor who favored Philip V and who was murdered by the pro-Aetolian faction

person.name: Ἄδμητος (1)
person.note: Synarch of the gynaikonomia in the year of Nikokrates (12), AD 86/7 or earlier

person.name: Ἀείμνηστος
person.note: A Spartiate who killed Mardonius in the battle of Plataea 479. He fell at Stenykleros in the third Messenian War.

person.name: Ἀθήναιος
person.note: In Spring 423, as representative from Sparta with full powers he made an armistice with Athens and traveled to Chalcidike to inform Brasidas

person.name: Ἀθ[ηνίων] (1)
person.note: [Subject] of an honorary decree for his good will to his fatherland

person.name: Ἀθηνίων (2)
person.note: Paidiskioros in the year of Soixiadas (2)

person.name: Ἀθηνίων (3)
person.note: Hyperetes [in the year of C. Julius Lampis (3)?], AD 118/9 or 119/20

person.name: Ἀθηνόδωρος
person.note: Poralla 33; Pausanias III 16.4 (J. N. Madvig Adversaria critica ad scriptores graecos et latinos 1706)
One of the Spartiates who in the end of the sixth century accompanied the king’s son Dorieus to Sicily

person.name: Ἀθηνόδωρος
person.note: IG V 1. 50b; SEG XI 505; Steinhauer, BSA 93, pp. 427-447, #1, plate 71a

person.name: Ἀθηράδας
person.note: Poralla 34; Africanus in Eusebius (Schoene) I 196; Olymp 24
Victor in Ol 20 = 700 at Olympia in the stadion

person.name: Ἀθύμβραδος
person.note: Poralla 35; Strabo XIV 650; (Etymologicum Magnum <T. Gaisford, Oxford 1848> s. v. [Akara—he is Cretan)
Brother of Athymbros and Hydreios, the mythical founders of Athymbrada in Asia Minor

person.name: Ἄθυμβρος?
person.note: Poralla 36; Strabo XIV 650; (Etymologicum Magnum <T. Gaisford, Oxford 1848> s.v. [Akara—Athymbrados is Cretan)
Brother of Athymbrados and Hydreios, the mythical founders of three places in Caria which through a synoecismos established Nysa

person.name: Αἰ— (2)
person.note: Dedication from the precinct of Athena Chalcioecus

person.name: Αἰγεύς
person.note: Son of Oiolykos the son of Theras
Aigeus is the eponym of the “great tribe in Sparta” (Hdt.), the Aegeidai.see Euryleon

person.name: Αἴθρα
person.note: Wife of Phalanthos, mythical founder of Tarentum

person.name: Αἴλ[ιος — ] (1)
person.note: IG V 1. 679; SEG XI 842 addendum; Rizakis #4

person.name: Πό(πλιος) Αἴλιος Ἀλκανδρίδας (2)Αἴλιος Ἀπολλώνιος (8)Πόπλιος Αἴλιος Δαμοκρατίδας (3)Πό(πλιος) Αἴλιος Διονύσιος (10)Πό(πλιος) Αἴλιος Δίων (4)Π(όπλιος) Α[ἴλ](ιος) Λε— (2) restored from ΤΑΝΛΕ—Μ(ᾶρκος) Αἴλιος Λεόντας (3)Αἴλιος Μητροφάνης Πό(πλιος) Αἴλ(ιος) Νικανδρίδας (4)Πό(πλιος) Αἴλιος Ὀνησιφόρος (8)Τιβέριος Κλαύδιος Αἴλιος Πρατόλαος (11) ὁ καὶ Δαμοκρατίδας[Αἴ]λιο(ς) Στρα[τ—]
Αίνηίδας
person.note: Dedication to Athena while he was gerousias

person.name: Αίνησίας
person.note: Poralla 39; Thucydides II 2; Xenophon Hellenica II 3.9

person.name: Αἰνησιμβρότα
person.note: Poralla 41; Bergk Poetae Lyrici Graeci III p 43 v. 73ff
Young woman’s name in a chorus by Alcman. Four of the singers lived with her.

person.name: Αἴνητος
person.note: A Laconian, who fell in war; an inscription of about the year 400 found

person.name: Αἴνητος
person.note: He was a victor at Olympia in the pentathlon and died shortly after the victory. He had a portrait statue in Amyclae

person.name: Αἱρήσ[ιππος]
person.note: He found his death in the field.

person.name: Αἱρήσιππος
person.note: Agatharchides of Cnidus mentioned him in the 30th book of his Europiaka. Book 27 has events of 244/3 BC. Book 31 has events of ca. 217 BC. Hairesippos, then, falls between these years.

person.name: Αἰσχρίων
person.note: Subject of an honorary decree by a city other than Sparta

person.name: Ἀκαμαντία (1)
person.note: Owner of a slave named Clodia

person.name: [Ἀκαμ]αντ[ία] (2)
person.note: Dedication, precinct of Apollo at Amyclae

person.name: Ἄκανθος
person.note: Poralla 46; Olymp 17; Africanus in Eusebius (Schoene) I 196. Philostratus Gymnastikos (Jüthner 12); Pausanias V 8.6; Dionysius Halicarnassus VII 72 (Cf. Eustathius Comm ad Iliadem Y 683, Pausanias I 44.1
A Spartiate who won the long distance run at Olympia, Ol. 15 = 720

person.name: Ἄκανθος
person.note: As a member of the college of ephors he concluded the peace of Nikias
and the alliance with Athens in spring 421.

person.name: Ἀκίνδοινος
person.note: Gravemarker: nine years old at death

person.name: Λούκιος Ἀπρών[ιος] Ἀκίνδυνος
person.note: Presbys of ephors in the year of C. Ju(lius) Lysikrates (1)a, AD 152/3
(Woodward, ABSA 26, 196 suggests he may have been the son of L. Apronius Praximenes and father/ancestor of L. Apronius Euelpistos.)

person.name: Ἀκματίδας Λακεδαιμόνιος
person.note: SEG XI 1227, XIV 355, XXIX 408; Hanson LGVI no 387 (hexameter plus three words), C. Gallavotti Metri 34; Moretti IAG 8; Olymp 160 (500 BC?)
Dedication by the victor of the pentathlon at the Olympic games, ca. 550-525 BC

person.name: Ἁκουσίων
person.note: Laconian inscription of very early time

person.name: Ἀκρατίδας
person.note: Naopoios in Delphi under the archon Demochares 338/7 and Kaphis

person.name: Ἀκρότατος (1)
person.note: Diodorus Siculus XIX 70.4-71.6a, [XX 29.1]; Pausanias I 13.5, III 6.2, {VIII 27.11-13, VIII 30.7 by name refers to Akrotatos (1) but in fact refers to Akrotatos (2)}; Plutarch Agis 3.6b, Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica) 216de, 240ef (grandson of Gyrtias); SEG XI 668(?); SEG XXV 444; IOlymp, Number 308; ICret II xxiii 12A; {SIG3 430, see Akrotatos (2)}
He opposed the decree to relieve the survivors of the battle of Megalopolis, 331 BC, of ignominya.
He commanded the forces of Acragas in Sicily, ca. 314, against Agathokles, but he was stripped of his command and forced to return to Spartaa.
He predeceased his father (who died in 309 BC).b

person.name: Ἀκρότατος (2)
person.note: Athenaeus IV 142b; Parthenius 23; Plutarch Agis 3.7a, Pyrrhus 26.18b, 28.4-7c, Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica) 240ef}; Pausanias III 6.6; {VIII 27.11-13, VIII 30.7 by name refers to Akrotatos (1) but in fact refers to Akrotatos (2)}; SIG3 430d (The editor assigns this inscription to Areus <1> and Akrotatos <1>, but the reference to “King” Akrotatos and “Queen” Chilonis seems to me rather to refer to this Akrotatos.)

Supposedly he committed adultery with the wife of his great uncle, Kleonymos (1), shaming him into leaving Spartab, a story which overlies the intense and bitter rivalry between the families of Areus I and Kleonymos.
He was a young man during Pyrrhus’ invasion of Laconia, 272 BC, but he took part in the fightingc.
He led the Lacedaemonian army to Megalopolis and was killed there, ca. 262 BC, by Aristodemos, the tyranta.

person.name: Αλε—, IG V 1. 172 = ἀλείπτας, see SEG XI 633
Ἀλέας
person.note: Damosios of the walls in the year of Archiadas (2)

person.name: Ἀ{λ}εξάκω[ν]
person.note: Gravemarker with a relief of a serpent

person.name: Ἀλεξάνδρ[α]
person.note: IG V 1. 770 (Ἀλκιλάδα ǀ Ἀλεξάνδρ[α]ς or Ἀλέξανδρ[ο]ς)
Mother of Alkida{m}a? or Alexandros (2), son of Alkiladas?

person.name: Ἀλέξανδρος
person.note: Poralla 50; Polyaenus VI 10; (date: Xenophon Hellenica IV 8.18-19)

As phrouarch an Alexandros handed over the fortified places of Aeolis to the Spartan commander Thibron. The time is established through the mention of the flute player Thersandros who is appropriate only to the second Asian campaign of Thibron. That Alexandros was Lacedaemonian is probable.

person.name: Ἀλέξανδρος
person.note: A Spartiate who in the winter 370/69 fell on the border of Laconia in a battle against the Argives

person.name: Ἀλέξανδ[ρος] (1)
person.note: Gymnasiarch for life; aristopolei[teu]tes for life

person.name: Ἰούλιος Ἀλέξανδρος
person.note: Gerousias in the year of P. Mem(mius) Eudamos

person.name: Ἀλέξανδρος (3) (= 1?)
person.note: Subject of honors: an athlete? (= Alexand[ros] <1>?)

person.name: Ἀλεξάνωρ (1)
person.note: Died before adulthood, buried with his mother and sister, survived by his father

person.name: (Γάιος Ἰούλιος) Ἀλεξᾶς (1)
person.note: Spondophoro[s] in the year of [C. Julius Eudamos (6)], AD 139/40-ca. 142

person.name: Ἀλεξᾶς (2)
person.note: Presbys of sphaireis in the year of Mnason (7), AD 160/1

person.name: Γά(ιος) Ἰούλιος Ἀλεξᾶς (3)
person.note: Nomophylax in the year of Attic[us], AD 133/4a
Ephor in the year of C. Julius Eudamos (6)b, AD 139/40-ca. 142

person.name: Ἀλεξικράτης (1)
person.note: IG V 1. 51 (Ἀλεσικράτης)a, 52b, 103 (cf. SEG XI 568)c; SEG XI 538d
Presbys of nomophylakes in the year of C. Julius Philoklidas (3)abd,

person.name: Ἀλεξίμαχος (1)
person.note: Lacedaemonian proxenos, and his descendants, of Polyrrhenia (in Crete)

person.name: Ἀλεξίμαχος (2)
person.note: IG V 1. 97a; SEG XI 564b, 565 (= IG V 1. 20b)c, [569—his name was omitted from the list of gerontes in the year of Aristokrates and added above = ] 642d
Gerousias for the first time in the year of C. Julius Philoklidas (3)ab, AD 91/2-95/6
[Gerousias] for the second timec {in the year of Menekles, 96/7}
Gerousias for the third time in the year of L. Volusenus Aristokrates (10a) {that is, his name was inadvertently omitted from the list and inscribed on the adjacent block)d

person.name: Ἀλεξίππα
person.note: Wife of Iphikratidas, mother of Eupylidas, Eraton, Chairis, Lykos, Agis, Alexon and Gylippos (all killed before Messene)

person.name: Ἀλεξιππίδας
person.note: Poralla 53; Xenophon Hellenica II 3.10; Thucydides VIII 58

person.name: Ἄλεξις
person.note: Presbys of ephors in the year of C. Julius Philoklidas (3)ab, AD 91/2-95/6

person.name: Μᾶρκος Αὐρήλιος Ἀλέξυς
person.floruit: MID II or EARLY III AD
person.note: Killed in a war against the Parthians (during the reign of either M. Aurelius or Caracalla—preferred by Spawforth, ABSA 79, 267-9) at the age of thirty; a relief shows him armed with spear, sword, and shield

person.name: Ἀλέξων
person.note: Son of Iphikratidas and Alexippa; he is supposed to have fallen with his brothers Eupylidas, Eraton, Chairis, Lykos, Agis, and Gylippos before Messene

person.name: Ἀλκαθόα
person.note: Poralla 55; Scholia to Aristophanes Equites 84; Suidas s. v. Παυσανίας (Ἀγειθέα); Polyaenus VIII 51 (Θεανώ); Diodorus XI 45,6; Nepos Pausanias 5,3

Mother of Pausanias and so also the mother of Nikomedes and wife of Kleombrotos. The different forms of the name most likely refer back to one form with 9 or 9. She is supposed to have brought a brick when her son Pausanias was in the temple of Athena Chalkioikos to wall him up.

person.name: Ἀλκαμένης
person.note: Poralla 56; Herodotus VII 204; Pausanias III 2.7, IV 4.4; FGrH (Apollodorus Chronika) II 244 (86/7)
Son of Teleklos and father of Polydoros.
The chronographers made him an older contemporary of Theopompos and concluded that the First Messenian War began under him. His reign was supposed to have been 32 years long, 785/4-754/3.

person.name: Ἀλκαμένης
person.note: Son of the ephor Sthenlaidas, led an army in 412 to king Agis II at Decelea. He was supposed to sail a fleet to Chios but he was repulsed by the Athenians at the Peiraeus and in the following battle was killed.

person.name: Ἀλκαμένης (1)
person.note: A Lacedaemonian murdered by the pro-Aetolian faction in Sparta

person.name: [Ἀλ]κανδρίδας (1)
person.note: Nomophylax in the year of Me(mmius) — (4)

person.name: Πό(πλιος) Αἴλιος Ἀλκανδρίδας (2)
person.note: SEG XI 844)]d; SEG XI 499e, 803f; IOlymp 238g; Orthia 330, 63h
Twice periodonikes and victor in many contestsbcf, dedication at Olympia for victory, ca. AD 221 and 225g, “best of the Greeks”bcf

Philocaesar, patriot, high priest of the emperorsabf, presbys of bideoi and subject of an honorary decree for his favors to his countryb; gymnasiarch and subject of an honorary decree for his acts as gymnasiarchf; [bideos]d; agoranomose
[2a] He is also to be recognized in the patronymic Alkandrida of P. Aelius Damocratidas in IG V 1. 305 = Bourguet, 130-32, no. 44 and in the following honorary inscriptions (all Severan)
[e] A. M.Woodward ABSA 26, 1923-25, 211-12 no. 10 with facsimile (XI 802)

[f] The same [?] should be postulated as father of P. Aelius Damocratidas in IG V 1. 655 (emended by L. Robert, REA 31, 1929, 13-18 and supplemented with two fragments by A. M. Woodward, ABSA 29, 1927-28, 41-43 no 65 with facsimile [XI 831], Spawforth, ABSA 79, 1984, 273

Remarks: Bradford distinguishes [1. 2f] [= p. 26 (2) from the Alcandridas of [2a-e] [= p. 27 (6)] regarding the latter as th grandfather of the former, whom he identifies with P. Aelius Alcandridas (III), son of Damocratidas, the prominent Spartan athlete and magistrate of the 1st half of the 3rd c. AD. This is rejected by A. J. S. Spawforth ABSA 80, 1985, 246, 247 n. 147, because he dates [1] in the 3rd quarter of the 2nd c. AD. He considers [1. 2a-e] as P. Aelius Alcandridas (II), the grandfather of P. Aelius Alcandridas (III). Settipani, 496 places his lifetime from AD 130 to after AD 155/65.
For the board of agranomoi in [1] see A. S. Bradford Chiron 10, 1980, 416 n. 33 and N. M. Kennell ZPE 85, 1991, 135n. 15.

Perhaps s. P. Aelius Nicandridas (LAC 16) and probably grands. P. Aelius Alcandridas (I) (LAC 5), presumably h. Pompeia Polla (I) (LAC 613) by whom f. P. Aelius Damocrates (LAC 9), grandf. P. Aelius Alcandridas (III) (LAC 7), perhaps also natural grandf. Ti. Claudius Aelius Partolaus (II) also known as Damocratidas (LAC 251); cf. stemmata in A. J. S. Spawforth, ABSA 80, 1985, 246 tab. 6 (Aelii Alcandridas and Settipani, 496 (the most important families of Roman Sparta); see infra, Appendix, Stemmata I and II.

person.name: Κλαύ(διος) Ἀλκανδρίδας (3)
person.note: Brother of Claudia Elpis (1) he kai Kallistonike
He and his sister paid for a memorial to their mother.

person.name: [Πό(πλιος) Αἴλ(ιος)] Ἀλκ[ανδ]ρίδας β[ουαγός] (4)
person.note: Rizakis 5; SEG XI 550; A. J. S. Spawforth, ABSA 80, 1985, 247 (cf. SEG 35, 1985, 328) [AD 140s]
Enseito[s] in the year of [C. Julius Eudamos <6>], AD 139/40-ca. 142

person.name: Π(όπλιος) Αἴλιος [Ἀλκανδρί]δα[ς]
person.note: Steinhauer, BSA 93, pp. 427-447, #3, plate 72a SEG 48, 1998, 457, l. 6;
Gerousias [for the second or more time] in the year of Nike[phoros h]o [Markou].

“Remarks: The date of the first is based on prosopographical considerations (Woodward loc. cit and A. J. S. Spawforth, ABSA 80, 1985, 210-11 n. 69). Which leads A. M. Woodward to restore the lost name of the eponymous official by analogy with IG V 1. 63 ll. 16-17, a catalogue of ephors in the term of C. Julius Eudamos, A. J. S. Spawforth, ABSA 80, 1985, 27 convincingly restores [Πό(πλιος) Αἴλ(ιος)] Ἀλκ[ανδ]ρίδας β[ουαγός] in [1. 1.16]. If this restoration is correct, prosopographically he is the earliest known and otherwise unattested member of this family with Roman citizenship, hence P. Aelius Alcandridas (1). Considering the chronological evidence of this inscription, it is most likely that he had become a Roman citizen through a personal grant of Hadrian on the occasion of one of the emperor’s two visits at Sparta (in AD 124/5 and 128/9). Cf. W. Weber, Untersuchungen zur Geschichte des Kaisers Hadrianus (Leipzig 1907)188-89 n. 671. 211 ns. 744-45; H. Box JRS 21 1931, 201; Chrimes Ancient Sparta 465; Halfmann Itinera principum, 137, 192; Cartledge and Spawforth 108. This would mean that Alcandridas was already of advanced age when ensitos.

“An unpublished inscription discussed in Steinhauer Eurykles testifies that C. Julius Eurykles Herculanus (LAC 462, ARC 105) died in the patronomate of (C. Julius) Nicephoros son of Marcus attested in [2], which should be dated to ca. AD 136/7, see G. Steinhauer, ABSA 93, 1998, 431 n 9. This date allows the identification of P. Aelius Alcandridas in [2] with the homonymous person in [1].

“For the nature of the post and title of bouagos [1(?), 2] in the Spartan agoge of the Roman imperial period see Cartledge and Spawforth, esp 203-204; Kennell, Institutions, 181-85 and id., Gymnasium esp 41-42, 108-09. Perhaps f. P. Aelius Nikandridas (LAC 16) see stemma in Spawforth, op. cit., 246 tab 6 (Aelii Alcandridae); see infra, Appendix, Stemma II.”

person.name: Ἄλκανδρος
person.note: A youth who was supposed to have wounded the lawgiver Lycurgus

person.name: Ἄλκαστος (1)
person.note: Gerousias for the second time in the year of C. Julius Philoklidas (3),

person.name: Ἄλκαστος (2)
person.note: IG V 1. 604; SEG XI addenda et corrigenda 812a, 817

person.name: Γά(ιος) Πομπώνιος Ἄλκαστος (3)
person.note: Son of the [brother] of C. Pomponius Alkastos (4)j
First cousin of C. Pomponius Agis (2) and Aristeas (2)j
Philocaesar, son of the city, patriotcdem; aristopoliteutesem
Paid for a memorial to his cousin, Agisj
Ephor in the year of Damokles (3)el, AD 132/3
High priest of the emperors for life by AD 132/3dlm
Presbys of nomophylakes in the year of Meniskosl, AD 135/6d
Ambassador to L. (Ceionius Commodus Verus) Caesar in Pannonia,

person.name: (Γά(ιος) Πομπώνιος) Ἄλκαστος (4)
person.note: Father of C. Pomponius Agis (2) and Aristeas (2)

person.name: Ἀλκείδης, Poralla 58a; Herodotus VI 61, cf. Ἀλκίδας
Ἀλκέτης
person.note: Poralla 59; Xenophon Hellenica V 4.56-57; Polyaenus II 7
As harmost he lost Oreos in Winter 377/6 and he was condemned for his carelessness in the loss of this important place.

person.name: Ἀλκιβία
person.note: Man(tis) and [hi]erothytes in the year of Aristokratidas (1)a
Subject of an honorary decree for her domestic virtue, the benefactions of her ancestors, and the blameless life she led with her husband for sixty years.c

person.name: Ἀλκιβιάδης
person.note: Father of Endios (who belonged to the college of ephors in 413/2)

person.name: [Ἀλ]κιβιάδ[ης] (1)
person.note: SEG XXVII (1977) 135; G. Daux, Études Delphique (BCH supplement 4, Paris, 1977) 51-57 (photo)
Dedication to Apollo at Delphi, 525-500 BC?

person.name: Ἀλκιβιάδης (2)
person.note: Livy XXXIX 35.6-37.21; Pausanias VII 9.2-4; Polybius XXII 1.9, 11.7-12.4; XXIII 4.3
A Lacedaemonian of great distinction who was exiled by Nabis and restored by the Achaean League
He was an envoy to the Romans in 184 BC, during which mission he denounced the Achaeans.

person.name: Ἀλκίδας
person.note: Father of the Spartiate Agetos (the friend of the king Ariston)

person.name: Ἀλκίδας
person.note: He was supposed to relieve Mytilene in the spring of 427, but he delayed so much on the trip, that at Delos the news reached him of the fall of Mytilene.

After a few voyages here and there along the coast of Asia Minor, he met a superior Athenian force and fled back to the Peloponnesusad. From Cyllene (where Brasidas was his military adviser) he sailed to Corcyra in the summer of 427.
After an indecisive sea battle he escaped from the Athenian fleet over the Isthmus of Leukasb.
In 426 Alkidas went as founder to Herakleia in Trachisc.

person.name: Ἀλκίδας
person.note: Nauarch of the year 374/3. He was apparently despatched to Sicily and
on the way was supposed to ravage Corcyra. The attack miscarried.

person.name: Ἀλκίδας
person.note: Eusebius Chronicorum Libri II (ed. A. Schoene), I, 207, 208
Victor in the stadion during the 134th Olympiad

person.name: Ἀλκιλάδας?
person.note: IG V 1. 770 (Ἀλκιλάδα ǀ Ἀλεξάνδρ[α]ς or Ἀλέξανδρ[ο]ς)

person.name: Ἄλκιμος
person.note: Twice brought offerings to Delphi, once under the archon Mnasimachos, again under Argillos 361/360.

person.name: Ἄλκιμος (2)
person.note: Victor of the boys’ ke[lea] in the year of N— (1) and the year of
Hierothytes in the year of Aristokratid[as] (1)a

person.name: Ἀλκινάδας
person.note: In 421 he took the oaths for the peace and the alliance with Athens

person.name: Ἄλκιππος
person.note: Husband of Damokrita, he was exiled from Sparta.

person.name: [Ἄλ]κιππος (1)
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Kallikrates (33)

person.name: Μᾶρ(κος) Αὐρ(ήλιος) Ἀλκισθένης
person.note: Rizakis 86 (ca. AD 223); IG V 1. 547a, [682]b, 683c; SEG XI 798
Sphaireus in the year of [P. Aelius Alkandridas (2)]b

Prostat[es of the] city with M. Aurelius Nikephoros (9)a; epimeletes of the patronomia in the fifth year of the god Lykourgos (3)c; paid for two statues in honor of Pomponius Panthales (2) Diogenes Aristeasa

person.name: Ἀλκισοίδας
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristokratidas (1)

person.name: Ἀλκμάν
person.note: Poralla 67; Bergk Poetae Lyrici Graeci III p 46, fr 24a; Herakleides Pontikos II 2 in Müller, Fragmenta Historicorum Graecorum, Paris, 1878, II p 210b; Suidas s. v.c; Anthologia Palatina VII 19, 709d; SEG XXIX 388 (S. E. Waywell, American Journal of Archaeology, 83 <1979>, 303, #49): mosaic portrait bust, associated with Sappho and Anacreone; Aelian varia historia XII 50; The Partheneion (D. L. Page), Oxford, 1951; Alcmani, I frammenti (Antonio Garzya), Naples, 1954; Antonio Farina, Studi sul Partenio di Alcmane, Naples, 1950; Athenaeus I 31cd, II 39a, III 81d, f, 110f, 111a, 114f, 115a, IV 140c, IX 373e, 374d, 390a, X 416cd, XI 498f-499a, XIII 600f, XIV 624b, [636d], 637a, 638e, 646a, 648b, XV 678c, 680f, 681a, XV 682a; Pausanias I 41.4, III 15.2, 3, 18.6, 26.2; Plutarch Lycurgus 28.10, Sulla 36.5, Moralia (de fortuna Romanorum) 318a, (de exilio 2) 599e, (quaestionum convivalium II 10.2) 659b, ( de Herodoti malignitate 14) 857f, ( aetia physica 24) 918a, ( de facie in orbe lunae ) 940a; Aristotle historia animalium 557a2; PW Supplement XI 19-29

The poet of Laconian choral lyric from the second half of the seventh century. Over his antecedents there is no agreement. (1) Alcman came from Sardisa. Added to that is the reference that Alcman was the slave of the Lacedaemonian Agesidasb. (2) Elsewherec the poet is described as Λάκων ἀπὸ Μεσσόας and is given Damas or Titaros as his father. (3) Alexander the Aetoliand takes a middle position in an epigram; he holds Alcman for a Laconian, but says that his ancestors came from Sardis. In a mosaic portrait bust Alcman was associated with Sappho and Anacreone.

person.name: Ἀλκυονεῦς
person.note: Gerousias for the second time in the year of P. Mem(mius) Eudamos

person.name: Ἀλύπητος
person.note: Fell in 377 as polemarch in the army of Agesilaos before Thebes

person.name: Ἀλφειός
person.note: He fell together with his brother Maron in 480 at Thermopylae and had a memorial in Sparta

person.name: Αὐρ(ήλιος) Ἀλφειός
person.note: Subject of an honorary decree as epi[tropos] of the emperors for his good will towards the Lacedaemonians

person.name: Ἀλώπεκος
person.note: Son of Irbos and brother of Astrabakos.
He is supposed to have been the fourth descendant of Agis I.

person.name: Ἀμείμητος
person.note: Gr(ammateus) [of bidyoi (?) ἐπὶ .....o]υς (Fragment 128 = [Δαμοκλέο]υς, AD 132/3 or [Ἀριστοκράτο]υς, AD 150/1?)

person.name: Ἀμεινίας
person.note: In the summer of 424 he was sent from Sparta to assess the activities of Brasidas in Thrace.

person.name: Ἀμείνιππος
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristokratidas (1)

person.name: Ἀμίαντος
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristokrati-
AMMAIO[Σ], IG V 1. 40, error for [γρ]αμματόφυλαξ, see SEG XI 482

person.name: Ἀμομφάρητος
person.note: One of the five Spartan arbiters who awarded Salamis to the Athenians around 610

person.name: Ἀμομφάρητος
person.note: In 479 he fought in the battle of Plataea as leader of the Pitanatans and fell there, before he was 30 years old. His initial refusal to obey the command to retreat before the Persians brought on the battle. He was judged to be the bravest of the Spartans.

person.name: Ἀμπελίδας
person.note: As ambassador to Argos shortly before 421 he tried to renew the thirty years truce

person.name: Ἀμύκλα
person.note: Poralla 75; Plutarch Alcibiades 1, Lycurgus 16, cf. Λανίκη

person.name: [Ἀ]μύκλας
person.note: Bidyos in the year of D— (2)

person.name: Ἀμφάρης
person.note: An ephor, who, under the pretense of being a friend, lured Agis IV from his sanctuary, conducted him to prison, prosecuted and executed the king, the king’s mother, Agesistrata, and grandmother, Archidamia

person.name: Ἀμφιάρης
person.note: The Oxyrhyncus Papyri, ed. Arthur S. Hunt, London, 1927, Part XVII, Number 2082; L. Moretti, Olympionikai, Lincei, 1955, page 133, number 515

person.name: Ἀμφικλῆς
person.note: He belongs, as do his descendants, to a fictitious series of Spartans who serve only to tie the Spartan hero Astrabakos to the royal line.

person.name: Ἀμφισθένης
person.note: He belongs, as do his descendants, to a fictitious series of Spartans who serve only to tie the Spartan hero Astrabakos to the royal line.

person.name: Γναῖος Ἀν— (1)
person.note: Enseitos [in the year of Alk]astos (3), AD 136/7

person.name: Ἀν— (4)
person.note: IG V 1. 171 (Upon examination of the squeeze at the Prussian Academy I found no trace of a P, only scratches more like scars. The P I suspect is due to the too acute desire of the epigrapher to read traces; if this is a name, then it is AN—.)
Name (?) in a list in the year of P—

person.name: ἈναΟ—
person.note: Eponymous patronomos in the year before Damarchos (3)

person.name: Ἀναξάνδρα
person.note: Daughter of the mythical king Thersandros of Kleonai, twin sister of Lathria
The pair were married to the sons of Aristodemos, Eurysthenes and Prokles.

person.name: Ἀναξανδρίδας I
person.note: King from the house of the Eurypontids
His reign falls at the turn of the seventh century.

person.name: Ἀναξανδρίδας II
person.note: Poralla 81; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.
King from the house of the Agids

In his first marriage he wed the daughter of his sister. Childless, he was compelled to take a second wife (the daugher of Prinetadas), by whom he had the later king Kleomenes I. By his first wife he then had Dorieus, Leonidas, and Kleombrotos.
Anaxandridas was the contemporary of Croesus and Ariston. He reigned from about 550-516.
Under him the long war with Tegea was ended.

person.name: Ἀνάξανδρος
person.note: Poralla 82; Herodotus VII 204; Pausanias III 3.4-5, 14.4, IV 15ff
King from the house of the Agids
His wife’s name was Leandris. Pausanias puts him in the time of thesecond Messenian war.

person.name: Ἀνάξανδρος
person.note: He was a victor in the Olympic games (Olympiad 88 = 428 BC ?) with the four horse chariot where also his father’s father had won in the Pentathlon.

person.name: Ἀνάξανδρος
person.note: Around 351 as leader of a Spartan detachment he was captured by the allied Thebans and Argives near Telphusa

person.name: Ἀναξίβιος
person.note: Poralla 86; Xenophon Anabasis a V 1.4, VI 1.16, VII 1.10-20 2.4-8;
In the spring of 400 he and his fleet were at Byzantium. He attempted to hinder the 10,000 from crossing into Europe (with one eye on the Persians)ac.
Around 389/8 he came to the Hellespont as harmost of Abydos. He was caught there by Iphicrates’ expedition to Abydos and fell in battleb.

person.name: Ἀναξίδαμος
person.note: Collateral relative of the house of the Eurypontids
According to the suspect list of Pausanias he was king at the end of the second Messenian war.

person.name: Ἀναξίλας
person.note: King from the house of the Eurypontids
He may have ruled about the middle of the seventh century.

person.name: Ἀναξίλας
person.note: He spoke as one of the five Spartan arbiters who awarded Salamis to

person.name: Ἄνδοκος
person.note: A Lacedaemonian who in the time of the archon Aischylos (Spring 363
bc) brought money to Delphi at the behest of Sparta

person.name: Ἀνδρέας
person.note: Victor in the stadion during the 179th Olympiad

person.name: Τιβ(έριος) Κλ(αύδιος) Ἄνδρεινος
person.note: [Gerousias in the year of Sipompos <2>, AD 126/7]

person.name: Ἀνδρίων (1)
person.note: Ephor and worshipper of Damoea-in-Thalamae in the year of

person.name: Ἀνδρόβιος
person.note: Victor in the men’s pentathlon at the Lycaean games (Arcadia), ca. 316

person.name: Ἀνδροκλείδας
person.note: Poralla 91; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.) 217c
A Lacedaemonian of unknown time who has a saying in Plutarch about

person.name: Ἀνδρόμαχος
person.note: (Lacedaemonian or Ambraciot) victor in the stadion during the

person.name: Ἀνδρομέδης
person.note: Was sent as ambassador to Boeotia and Athens in 420

person.name: Ἀνδρομέδης
person.note: Witness on a dedicatory inscription from Taenarum in the beginning of the fourth century in the time of the ephor Eudamidas

person.name: Ἀνδρόνικος (1)
person.note: Ag[oran]omos (presbys?) in the year of Theoxenos (3)

person.name: Ἀνδρόνικος (3)
person.note: Kathartes in the year of Nikokles (7)

person.name: Ἀνδρόνικος (4)
person.note: Gerousias in the year of L. V[o]lusenus Aristokrates (10), AD 100/1

person.name: Ἀνδρόνικος (5)
person.note: Presbys of ephors in the year of C. Julius Eudamos (6), AD 139/40-

person.name: [Ἀν]δροτελί[α] (1)
person.note: Dedication in the precinct of Apollo, Amyclae

person.name: Ἀνέγκλητος
person.note: [Gra]mmato[phylax] in the year of Se[x. Pom]peius — (3)b. i.e.
Ephor in the year of Kallikrates (26)a, AD 151/2

person.name: Ἀνήριστος
person.note: Father of the Spartiate Sperthias, who was sent to Xerxes in 480

person.name: Ἀνήριστος
person.note: He was instrumental in the campaign at Halieis, perhaps in 459, against the Athenians.
In 430 he went to the king of Thrace Sitalkes to try to win him over to the Spartan side, but he was taken prisoner by Sadokos, the son of Sitalkes and handed over to the Athenians who executed him.

person.name: Ἀνθεσφόρος
person.note: IG V 1. 65; SEG XI 523; Steinhauer, BSA 93, pp. 427-447, #8, plate 75a

person.name: Ἄνθης
person.note: Poralla 96; Stephanus Byzantius s. v. 9; Alan Griffiths, ‟Was Cleomenes Mad,” Classical Sparta: Techniques Behind Her Success, Norman, 1988, pp. 62-67

He was supposed to have been flayed by Kleomenes I. Stephanus identifies Anthes with the mythical founder of Anthana, the son of Poseidon (and not a Lacedaemonian) and suggests some sort of symbolic act.

person.name: [Ἀν]θίδας
person.note: “Kalas [An]thida set up this memorial to [G]laukat[ias] his son”

person.name: Κλα(ύδιος) Ἀνείκητος (1)
person.note: Gra(mmateus) in the year of Eurykles (2), AD 116/7

person.name: Ἄννα Ἀφροδείτω
person.note: Gravemarker for herself, Beithys, and Gergyllion
(Aphrodeito may be the genitive of Aphrodeitos, hence, Anna, the daughter of Aphrodeitos)

person.name: Ἄνσε[τος] (2)
person.note: Aristokr[ates (3) kasen to him in the year of Mena]lkid[as] (3)

person.name: Ἀνταλκίδας
person.note: Poralla 97; Plutarch Artaxerxes 21-22a; Agesilaus 23b, 32c; Xenophon Hellenica IV 8.12-16d; V 1.6, 25-29, 36e; VI 3.12f; Diodorus XIV 110g; Athenaeus II 48e; David Whitehead, Liverpool Classical Monthly IV (1979), 191-193, on the form of the name

In winter 393/2 he travelled to Sardis to the satrap Tiribazos from whom he received money for support of the fleetd. As nauarch of the year 388/7 he sailed from Aigina to Ephesus and betook himself to the Great King with whom he worked out the terms of the peace named after himeg.
After that he relieved Nikolochos who had been shut up in Abydose.
At the time of the 371 peace conference in Sparta he was spending time at the court of the Persian kingf.
In 370/69 he held the office of ephorc.
It was probably in 367 that he travelled for the third time to the king. There, however, when his mission was fruitless, he committed suicidea.

person.name: Ἀντιαλκίδας
person.note: Gerousias in the year of Serippos (3)

person.name: Ἀντίβιος (1)
person.note: [Benefactor] and proxenos of Thera, ca. 100 BCb
Subject of a memorial by the damos of Therac

person.name: Ἀντίγονος (1)
person.note: Syna[rch] of the agoranomia in the year of [Pa]us[a]nias (3)

person.name: [Ἀν-- or Βυ]τίδας
person.note: A name from a relief depicting a nude bearded man who is holding the hand of a woman clad in a Doric chiton; there is a rakelike object between them

person.name: Ἀντικλείδας
person.note: Father of Leon, who won a victory with his father’s horses

person.name: Ἀντικράτης
person.note: A Spartiate who at the battle of Mantinea in 362 killed Epaminondas and thereby won the title of Machairion and public meals for his descendants.

person.name: Ἀντίλα[ς] (2)
person.note: Lacedaemonian dicast praised by an Eretrian decree

person.name: Ἀντιλέων
person.note: A Lacedaemonian who in the year of the archon Mnasimachos (363/2) at
the behest of Sparta brought money to Delphi

person.name: Αντίμαχος (1)
person.note: Gerousias in the year of Serippos (3)

person.name: Ἀντιμενίδας
person.note: Was an ambassador to Athens in 420 and was occupied in Boeotia

person.name: Ἀντίοχος
person.note: Poralla 102; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.) 217e
Ephor of the year 338/7 during which Philip, after the battle of
Chaeronea, decreed the separation of Messenia from Sparta

person.name: [Ἀν]τίοχος (1)
person.note: Spondophoros in the mid 90’s AD (the spondophoros often was the son of a man holding office; this inscription then may come from the same year as the following)

person.name: Ἀντίοχος (2)
person.note: Gerousias for the second time in the year of C. Julius Philoklidas (3),

person.name: Γάι(ος) Ἰούλιος Ἀντίπατρος (1a)
person.note: Diokles (2) and T(i.) Clau(dius) Agathokles (4) kasen to himde
Philocaesar and patriotc, agonothetes of the Greater Eurykleian gamesa; eponymous patronomos, AD 113/4 or 114/5bcf

person.name: Γάι(ος) Ἰούλιος Ἀντίπατρος (1b)
person.note: Is this Antipatros the grandson of Antipatros (1a)?
Ensitos in the year of Kallikrates (26), AD 151/2

person.name: Ἀντ[ί]πα[τρος] (2=3)
person.note: Rizakis 258 (Stemmata I, VII, VII); IG V 1. 519 (+ 582, cf. SEG XI 811)
Paid for a memorial in honor of his mother

note.hi: or

person.name: Ἄντιππος
person.note: He was one of the Spartiates who concluded the Peace of Nicias and the alliance with Athens in 421.

person.name: Ἀντισθένης
person.note: Poralla 104; Thucydides VIII 39, 42; Xenophon Hellenica III 2.6-9
A Spartiate who in the winter of 412/11 travelled from Laconia to Knidos with a fleet and united with the nauarch Astyochos. In Spring 398 we find him in Lampsakos with Derkylidas.

person.name: Ἀντίωρος
person.note: He can only be as historical as Lycurgus himself

ΑΡ

person.name: Ἄρακος
person.note: Poralla 107; Xenophon Hellenica II 3.10.1a,7b; III 2.6-9c; VI 5.33d; Pausanias X 9.9e; Plutarch Lysander 7f; FDelph III I 51g (epigram)

Eponymous ephor of the year 409/8a. Nominal nauarch of the year 405/4b. In spring 398 with Naubates and Antisthenes he was sent to Dercylidas in Asia Minorc. In winter 370/69 he was an ambassador in Athensd. (But is the ambassador a second Arakos?)

person.name: Ἀράτα (1)
person.note: Subject of an honorary decree for her sensible and pious life; dedication to Demeter and Kore

person.name: Ἀράτα (2)
person.note: Poralla 108; IG IV2 122 xxi ( = SIG3 1169 xxi)

A sufferer from dropsy. Her mother went to the shrine of Asclepius in Epidaurus to find a cure. In her sleep she saw Asclepius decapitate her daughter—a liquid flowed from her head—and he rejoined head and neck. The mother hurried home to Sparta, found her daughter cured, and the dream fulfilled.

person.name: Ἄρατος
person.note: Father of Phalanthos (according to myth the founder of Tarentum)

person.name: Ἄρατος (1)
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristokra-

person.name: Ἄρατος (2)
person.note: A Lacedaemonian honored by Cotyrta for his benefactions. He and his descendants were granted the rights of proxenos and benefactor: to own land and a house, to contract marriage, to have the protection of law, exemption, asylum in war and peace, and the other customary rights.

person.name: Ἀργιλεωνίς
person.note: Poralla 110; Plutarch Lycurgus 25, Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v. Brasidas 4) 219d

person.note: He fell into disfavor with Tiberius and was ruined.

person.name: Ἀρέτης, Poralla 111a, Diodorus XIV 70.3, cf. Ἄριστος

person.name: Ἄρευς

A Laconian who made a remark on an epigram about the tyranny in
Selinus (i.e., time of Dorieus’ expedition {?}, see Euryleon 327)

person.name: Ἄρευς
person.note: Poralla 113; Antoninus Liberalis 12 = Pausanias III 13.8 Areios
Laconian poet of unknown time (but PW Supplement I 127:
“Areios” is probably Asinos (of Samos), not Areus)

person.name: Ἄρευς (1) I
person.note: Diodorus Siculus XX 29.1a; Justin XXIV 1.5; Pompeius Trogus prologi 26; Pausanias I 13.5; III 6.2-6b; VI 12.5-6, 15.9; Plutarch Agis 3.6-7c, Pyrrhus 26.17-19d, 27.2e, 29.11f, 30.4, Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica) 217f g; Josephus Antiquitates Judaicae XII 225-27h, XIII 167 (9); 1 Maccabees 12.1-23; Athenaeus IV 142b; ICret II xxiii 12Ai; IOlymp 308j; IG IV 1. 332; SEG XXV 444k; SEG XI 668 (?—Dedication to Athena); [SIG3 430, see Areus (2) II]; Grunauer, pp. 112-113 (Gr. I-II, Tafel 1: ΒΑΣΥΛΕΟΣ ΑΡΕΟΣ)
Father of Akrotatos (2), king of Sparta

He succeeded to the throne despite the fact that Kleonymos (1), son of Kleomenes II, was alive. Kleonymos, however, was given command of the armies. Their rivalry, intensified, no doubt, by Akrotatos’ adultery with the wife of Kleonymos, led to Kleonymos’ leaving Sparta and joining Pyrrhus.bd
Areus was an active king, forming connections in Sicilyg, Creteei, Egyptjk, and possibly Judaeah.

He attempted to restore the Spartan hegemony of the Peloponnesus and opposed the Macedonian forces in Greece, although he was forced into a brief alliance with them to forestall the invasion of Pyrrhus into Laconiaf.
He was killed in an attempt to force the Macedonian lines at Corinth, 265 BCc

person.name: Ἄρευς (2) II
person.note: In SIG3 430 the Delphians grant proxenia to “King Areus, son of King Akrotatos and Queen Chilonis.” The editor believes that this refers to Areus I, since it seemed unlikely to him that the Delphians would grant proxenia to a child, albeit a king. Akrotatos, however, the father of Areus I, was not a king. There is but one king Akrotatos and he is the father of Areus II. Moreover, the Chilonis of the inscription might well be the widow of Kleonymus and lover of Akrotatos the king [26.17-18].)
He was born after the death of his father at Megalopolis, 262 BC. Leonidas (1), the son of Kleonymos (1), was regent. He was an Agiad king.
He died of disease when he was eight years old.

person.name: Ἄρευς (3)
person.note: Livy XXXIX 35-37; Pausanias VII 9.2-4; Polybius XXII 1.9 & 11.7-12.4; XXIII 4.3
He was exiled from Sparta by Nabis and restored against the wishes of the government of Sparta by the Achaean league.
In 184 BC he was an envoy to the Romans and he denounced the Achaean league.

person.name: Τ(ίτος) Τρεβελληνός Ἄρευς (4)

person.name: Ἀριστομενίδας
person.note: Belonged to the Spartan court of five men who sentenced the Plataeans to death in 427. In 396 he was sent as ambassador to Thebes.

Pausanias says that he was the father of the mother of Agesilaos, which is totally impossible (because of the dates). He may have been the father-in-law of Agesilaos, that is the father of Kleora. Or the name of the father of the mother of Agesilaus may have been Aristomenidas, but a different person. See Μελησιππίδας.

person.name: Ἀρίστων
person.note: Poralla 138; Herodotus I 67, VI 61-63; Pausanias III 7.7-8; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s.v.) 218ab
King from the house of the Eurypontids

Because his first two marriages were childless, he married a third time ... the wife of his friend Agetos. From this marriage came the later king Damaratos. Ariston was a contemporary of Croesus and Anaxandridas. While he was king the long war against Tegea was ended.

person.name: Ἀρίστων

Maximus;” synthetes to Neapolis, not accepting travel expenses; Panhellen, gerousias, ephor during the disturbances (ἐπὶ τῶν νεωτερισμῶν), gerousias again, tamias in the year of Sokrates (5), after AD 168

person.note: A pai(anias) in the year of Me(mmius) Damares (5) and a worshipper of Damoea-in-Thalamae

person.name: Ἀρκεσίλαος
person.note: He won twice at Olympia (448-444?) with the four horse chariot and had a portrait there because of the victory

person.name: Ἀρκεσίλαος (1)
person.note: One of the three friends of king Agis IV who visited him in his asylum and once formed an escort for him (so he could leave his place of asylum and bathe)

person.name: Ἀρκεσίλαος (2)
person.note: In 184 BC he accompanied Agesipolis (2) on a journey to Rome as envoy for a group of exiles and was killed by pirates

person.name: Ἀρκεσί[λαος] (3)
person.note: Ἄρκεσος, Poralla 141a; Plutarch Moralia (de genio Socratis) 598f, cf.

person.name: Ἄρκισσος
person.note: Poralla 142; Plutarch Moralia (de genio Socratis 34) 598f; Pelopidas 12-13

One of the three harmosts who in the year 379 gave up the Cadmeia prematurely. He was executed in Corinth for that. (Though not stated specifically he is certainly a Spartiate as his two colleagues were.)

person.name: Ἀρμένας
person.note: He was sent to Rome as a hostage, ca. 195 BC,abcd where he died.b

person.name: Ἁρμόνικος (1)
person.note: Victor in the men’s pentathlon at Pelasgian Larissa

person.name: Τιβέριος Κλαύδιος Ἁρμόνικος (2a = 5)
person.note: Rizakis 296-299 q.v.; IG V 1. [20b, (cf. SEG XI 565: Τιβ(έριος) Κλα(ύδιος) Ἁ[ρμ]ό[νεικος])a, 79b, 97 (SEG XI 564)c, 169 (SEG XI 632)d, 275e, 480f; SEG XI 546g, 563h
Father of (Ti. Claudius) Pleistoxenos (1 = 2)a and Ti. Claudius Xenophanes (1)ab
A member of the Cynosurian obef
Honored by his obe and by the city in the year of C. Julius Lakon (3) for his generosity as gymnasiarchf

(His sons were sysseitoi in the year of Kleandros <5>, AD 99/100, which may indicate that he held an office in that year, but not ephor, nomophylax, or bideos, which are known <SEG XI 512, 539 {IG V 1. 79}, 609>)b
Gerousias for the second time in the year of C. Julius Philoklidas (3)c, AD 91/2-95/6 or earlier
Gerousias for the third time [in the year of Menekles]a, AD 96/7

person.name: Τιβ(έριος) Κλαύδιος Ἁρμόνικος (2b)
person.note: Grandson of Ti. Claudius Harmoneikos (2a), hence a member of the Cynosurian obe

“Took the honors of the aristopoliteia according to the law and from the demos exactly as the godlike emperor Caesar Trajan Hadrian Augustus and Aemilius Juncus the dikaiodotes wrote concerning him.”a
(Aemilius Juncus was the legatus propraetore in Achaea, AD 128/9, cf.
IG II/III2 4210, see also Rizakis 20, AD 127-137.)

person.name: Ἁρμοστής
person.note: Was besieged by the Athenians, time unknown. Perhaps not a proper name but the title of his position, harmost

person.name: Ἀρξιλαίδας
person.note: Leader of an army detachment who used a stratagem

person.name: Ἀρτέμας (1)
person.note: Synarch of the gynaikonomia in the year of Kleonymos (5)

person.name: Ἀρτέμις
person.note: Gravemarker with relief: clothed human figure, right hand hanging down and holding a cup

person.name: Ἀρτεμίσιος
person.note: IG V 1. 102 (cf. SEG XI 579); SEG XI 490, 544

person.name: Ἀρτέμω
person.note: Gravemarker: “the companion of Sabeinos for fourteen years but now among the gods”

person.name: Αὐρήλιος Ἀρτέμων

Victor of the stadion in Ol. 36 = 636 BC

person.name: Ἀρχελαίδας
person.note: The name is secure. The circumstances suggest that he is a Lacedaemonian. That he is a nauarch (of the year 397/6) and predecessor of Pollis is a conjecture: Πόλλις] ναύαρχος ἐκ Λακε[δαίμονος εἰς τὴ]n Ἀρχελαίδα κατα[στὰς διάδοξος].

person.name: Ἀρχελάεις
person.note: Gravemarker with an entreaty that there be no desecration of the tomb

person.name: Ἀρχέλαος
person.note: Poralla 147; Herodotus VII 204, Pausanias III 2.5-6, Eusebius I 225
He was supposed to have taken the city of Aigys
Ancient chronographers give him a reign of 60 years, 885/4-826/5, and make him a contemporary of Charillos

person.name: Ἀρχίαδας (1)
person.note: He dedicated a statue to his father-in-law.

person.name: Ἀρχίαδας (4)
person.note: Epimeletes [of the repairs] of the theatre, ca. AD 359

person.name: Ἀρχίας
person.note: Name on an early inscription found in Geraki

person.name: Ἀρχίας
person.note: Poralla 150; Herodotus III 55; Plutarch Moralia (de Herodoti malignitate 22) 860c
A Spartiate from Pitane, fell around 525 in the battle against Polykrates before Samos

person.name: Ἀρχίας
person.note: Contemporary of Herodotus; he is probably the father of the nauarch Samios, whom Sparta sent to help Cyrus the Younger in 401

person.name: Ἀρχιδάμεια
person.note: Priestess of Demeter in Laconian Aigila; she was supposed to have freed the imprisoned Aristomenes in the Second Messenian War

person.name: Ἀρχιδάμια
person.note: Mother of Agesistrata, Agesilaos (2), {and Archidamos (2) IV?}b

Grandmother of Agis (1) IV, Archidamos (3) <V>, and Hippomedon (1)a <Polybius (IV 35.13) states that Hippomedon was in the line of Eurypontid succession, which would be readily understandable if he were the grandson of a king. Agesilaos, his father, was the son of a Eudamidas. Eudamidas I was a Eurypontid. It seems likely then that Archidamia was the wife of Eudamidas I.>

During the invasion of Laconia by Pyrrhus, 272 BC, Archidamia opposed a plan to send the women and children of Sparta to Crete. She organized the women to fortify the city, carry weapons, and treat the wounded. She aided and encouraged the Spartan soldiers.c
She was one of the wealthiest women in Sparta, but she supported the reforms of Agis IV with both her money and her influence.a
She was executed after his fall in 241 BCb

person.name: Ἀρχιδαμίδας
person.note: Poralla 153; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.) 218b; Lycurgus 20
A Spartiate contemporary of Hecataeus (of Abdera?)—he responded to a criticism of Hecataeus and to a question about the number of Spartiates

person.name: Ἀρχίδαμος
person.note: According to the false kings’ list of Pausanias he was a king from the Eurypontid house, son of Theopompos and father of Zeuxidamos. He is supposed to have died before his father. Perhaps to be identified with Archidamos (Poralla 154).

person.name: Ἀρχίδαμος
person.note: According to the false kings’ list of Pausanias he was a king from the Eurypontid house and son of Anaxidamos and father of Agasikles

person.name: Ἀρχίδαμος II
person.note: King from the house of the Eurypontids
Father of Agis II (from his first marriage with his step-aunt Lampido)ab and Agesilaos II and Kyniska (by his second wife Eupolia)acfg

When shortly before 476 Leotychidas had to go into exile at Tegea, his grandson Archidamos assumed the rulee. Whether he had already taken part in the battles of Tegea in 473 and Dipaia can not be known. He was first mentioned in the great earthquake in Sparta in 464, where he saved the state through his presence of mindh. He distinguished himself in the ensuing battles against the Messeniansd.
Archidamos commanded the first invasion of Attica in the year 431 and 430klm. In 429 he took Plataea and in the next year led an army into Attica for the third time.no
He became sick and died at the latest in the Winter 427/6.

person.name: Ἀρχίδαμος III
person.note: King from the house of the Eurypontids (born about 400)
Son of Agesilaos II and Kleora.
Father of Agis III, Eudamidas I and Agesilaosgmo
In 371 he led the defeated army of Kleombrotos back from Megara to Sparta. (Diodorus XV 54-55 in error puts Archidamos also at the battle of Leuctra.)bc
In the years 367 and 364 Archidamos campaigned against the Arcadians in the fielddei.
Isokrates put a speech in his mouth that he was supposed to have delivered at the Peace Congress in Sparta in 366/5p.
In 362 he was occupied in the defense of Sparta against the Thebansfj.
After the death of Agesilaos II in the winter of 360/59 he ascended the thronek.

At the outbreak of the Sacred War Archidamos in secret helped the Phociansmq. Around 352 he fought against Megalopolisr, and in 346 led an army to help Phocis, but because of the ambiguities of the situation among the Phocian leaders returned to Sparta with nothing accomplishedsv.

After that he was sent to Italy to help Tarentum in a war against the Lucanians. He sailed first to Crete where he refounded Lyttos. In Italy he fought a battle at Mandonion 338—on the seventh of the month Metageitnionl—lost the battle and his lifegmtuv.
He had a portrait bust in Olympian and a statue in Delphiw.

person.name: Ἀρχίδαμος (1)
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of

person.name: Ἀρχίδαμος (2) IV
person.note: {Grandfather of Agis IV, Archidamos (3) <V>, and Hippomedon (1)}
He fought a battle with Demetrius near Mantinea, where he was defeated, 294 BCbc There is no further mention of Archidamos in the sources and he may have been killed in this battle.

person.name: Ἀρχίδαμος (3) {V}
person.note: Son of Eudamidas (2) II and Agesistrata
First cousin and son-in-law of Hippomedon (1)a
Father of two sons, names unknowna

Upon the execution of his brother he fled into exile in Messene and lived there until he was persuaded by Kleomenes (1) III to return and become the Eurypontid kingbdef. When he returned, he was murderedbcef.
Whether he actually became king is unclear.

person.name: Ἀστύοχος

person.name: Βρασίδας (1)
person.note: Poralla 177; Thucydides II 25a, 85-94b, III 69c, 76-81d, IV 11-12e, 70-74f, 78-88g, 111-116h, 120-129i, 135j, V 2-3k, 6-11l; Aristotle Ethica Nicomachea V 10 p. 1134b m; Polyaenus I 38n; Plutarch Lycurgus 25o, Lysander 1, 18p, Nicias 9.3, Moralia (apophthegmata regum et imperatorum s. v. Augustus 14) 207f q, 79e, 240c, 343a,d, 347b, 349d, 400f, 401c, 548b; Pausanias III 14.1r; Libanius, ed. Foerster II 359,13s; orationes 18.281, 19.45, 64.10; Diodorus XII 43.2t, 62u; Xenophon Hellenica II 3.10v; Chariton VIII 2.12; Aristophanes Wasps 475; Plato Symposium 221c; Lucian quomodo historia conscribenda sit 49; Isocrates orationes VI 53
In 431 he saved Methone from an Athenian attacka. He was the eponymous ephor of the year 431/30, though he was quite young (but still met the age qualification)tv.

In the next year under the command of Knemos he took part in the sea battle at Rhion and Naupaktos and in the attack on Salamisb. In the same duty he took part in 427 in the expedition against Corcyra of Alkidascd. In the battle at Pylos he distinguished himself and was badly woundedeu.

In the next year he gathered his forces in Corinth and Sicyon for the Thracian expedition and in Autumn 424 reached Thessaly. After a short march against the Lyncestan king Arrhabaios he turned himself to Chalcidice and brought over the wavering cities to his side. He fought from time to time with various fortune against Arrhadaios and the cities Potidaea and Torone, and in the second half of October 422 triumphed finally over Kleon in the decisive batttle at Amphipolis, but in it he, himself, was fatally woundedfghijkln. The citizens of Amphipolis buried him in the city and honored him as hero and founderlm.

In Sparta a cenotaph was erected for himr. Brasidas and the Acanthians had a common treasury in Delphip. Direct descendants of his are known from Augustan timesq. The heroism of Brasidas remained proverbial for a long times.

note.hi: Κλ(αύδιος) Βρασίδας (2)

person.name: Γοργώπας
person.note: Poralla 193; Xenophon Hellenica V 1.5-13; Demosthenes XI 76

In 389/8 he was epistoleus of the nauarch Hierax; as such he was occupied in Aegina. From there he went with Antalkidas, the nauarch of the next year, to Ephesus and then travelled back to Aegina, where he defeated the Athenians at sea in a moonlit battle. Soon thereafter he fell into an ambush in Aegina (set by Chabrias) and was killed along with eight other Spartiates.

person.name: Γύλιππος
person.note: Poralla 196; Aelian varia historia XII 43a; Thucydidesb VI 93, 104, VII 1-7, 21-23, 46, 52-86; Diodorus XIII 7-8c, 106.8-10d; Plutarch Nicias e 19-21, 26-28; Comparatio Timoleon et Aemilius Paulus 2f; Lysander 16-17g; Lycurgus 30.5; Alcibiades 23.2, Dion 49.5; Mor. 10c; Lucian quomodo historia conscribenda sit 38; Justin IV 4.7, 10, 5.9; Athenaeus VI 234a; Isocrates orationes VI 53
He was a mothaxa, that is, his father had lost his citizenship due to criminal acts and Gylippos, apparently, had entered the agoge sponsored by someone else.

When the Athenians lay siege to Syracuse during the Peloponnesian War, Gylippos was sent by the Spartans to help the Syracusans. He organized the defense, defeated and destroyed the Athenian forces.bce
After that Gylippos was sent back to Sparta by the Syracusans because of his greed and his imperiousness.f

We find him next in the fleet of Lysander. He was sent back to Sparta after the battle of Aegospotami with the valuable booty. Gylippos embezzled part of it, was caught and condemned to death and fled into exile.dg

person.name: Γύλιππος
person.note: He fought together with his six brothers at an unknown time against Messenia (thus after 369 BC) and was the only survivor.

person.name: Γύλιππος (1)

person.name: Δαμακίων (1)
person.note: Ephor in the year of Damokles (3), ca. 132/3a[c]

person.name: Δαμάρατος
person.note: Poralla 210; Herodotus VI 50-51a, 61-63b, 64c, 65-66d, 70e, 75f, VII 3g, 101-104h, 209i, 234-235j, 239k, VIII 65l; Plutarch Moralia (mulierum virtutes 4) 245c-f m, (de Herodoti malignitate 31. 3) 864f n, Themistius 29o; Polyaenus VIII 33p; Pausanias III 4. 3-5q; Diogenes Laertius I 72r Xenophon Hellenica I 6s; Athenaeus I 29f t; Olymp 157
King from the house of the Eurypontids.
Son of king Ariston and the last of his three wives.a
He was married to Perkalos, the daughter of Chilon, whom he had taken from her groom, Leotychidas.c
After the death of his father Damaratos began his reign, at the latest in 510.c He was the only one of the Spartan kings to win the chariot race at Olympia, 504 BCeu
In spring of 506 he and Cleomenes I led an army against Athensf
Despite the sources he could hardly have taken part in the operation against Argos in 494.mp
As Kleomenes in 491 moved against Aegina, to seize the leaders of the party friendly to Persia, Damaratos chose, through his intrigue, to bring this maneuver to nothing.a
As revenge for that he was now driven from the throne by Kleomenes and Leotychidas, ca. 491.bcdq
Damaratos escaped from Sparta under the pretext of a trip to Delphi and fled through Elis and Zacynthos to the Persian king Darius.eg
In 480 he accompanied Xerxes on the expedition against Greece.hijklnr
As a reward for his valuable service he received the cities Teuthrania, Pergamon, Halisarna, and Gambreion after the invasion as his family possession.st
Damaratus was still alive in 464 when Themistocles came to the Great King at Susa.o

person.name: Δαμάρατος

Son of Prokles and Pythia (the daughter of the philosopher Aristotle)
Descendant of the exiled king Damaratos

person.name: Δαμοκλῆς (11)
person.note: Archaiologikon Deltion 24 (1969) Chronica p. 136, pl. 132 (BCH 1971 p. 887, fig. 182, 183); ArchAnAth 1970, 260-2)
Name on the base for (four) statues, one to Julia Mamaea (AD 221-2)

The inscriptions reads Δαμοκλῆς < Ἀρι—. If < were the patronymic, < = Δαμοκλέους, and Ἀρι—the grandfather, we would find it written (most likely) Δαμοκλῆς < τοῦ Ἀρι--. We may have an honorific title here, as ἀριστοπολιτεύτης, which certainly makes sense, given that his name appears on the base of four statues.

person.name: Δαμώνων
person.note: Poralla 219; IG V 1. 213; Moretti, IAG 16 (440-435 bc)

According to an inscription found in Sparta he and his horses had won victories at different contests. The letter forms seem to indicate the second half of the fifth century. The three ephors named in the inscription do not appear in the list of Xenophon (Hellenica II 3.10), so the inscription must be dated either before 433/2 or after 404/3. That they won over fifty victories, but none in Olympia (Pausanias VI 2.1-2: list of Lacedaemonian victors) suggests that their victories fell in the period when the Spartans were excluded from the Olympic games, 420 to 400 or 396 (Thucydides V 50; Xenophon Hellenica III 2.21; Pausanias VI 2.1-3) and that the named ephors held that office after 404/3. The letter forms are not decisive. (contra Moretti!)
