person.name: Πάτρων (1)
person.note: Name in a catalogue from Oetylus

person.name: Πάτρων (2)
person.note: Name in a catalogue from Oetylus

person.name: Παυσανίας
person.note: Poralla 595; Thucydides I 94-95a, 107b, 128-134c, III 26d, V 16e; scholia to Aristophanes Equites 84f; Herodotus V 32g, IX 10h, 19-88i; Pausanias III 4.9- 10j, 17.7-9k; Plutarch Aristides 14-20l, 23m, Cimon 6n, 9o, Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.) 230ce p; Diodorus XI 29.4-32q, 44-6r; Justin IX 1s; Nepos Pausanias 4-5t; Aristotle Politica V 1 p. 1301bu, 1307a4; Athenaion politeia 23.4; Libanius epistulae 1518.6 (his tomb in Sparta), orationes 64.83 (though “king”), declamationes 1.159; Anthologia Graeca VI 197; Athenaeus IV 138bc. XII 535e, 536ab, 543b; PW XVIII 2.2563-2578 (Schaefer)
Collateral relative of the royal house of the Agids
Father of the later king Pleistoanax, and of Kleomenes and of Aristoklesabdef

After the death of his father in 479 Pausanias took over the regency for his cousin Pleistarchoshj. In the same year he defeated the Persians at Plataeailq. In spring 478 P. sailed at the head of the Greek fleet to Cyprus and then to the Hellespont. Here he acted so arrogantly and had such a dubious attitude towards the Persians that the Ionian ship captains refused to obey him and transferred the command to Athens. Pausanias was recalled, set before the court in Sparta on a charge of medism but not convictedacgmnr.
He was supposed to have won a victory at the Olympic gamesp.

After that he sailed on his own in 477 to Byzantium, took Sestos and entered into negotiations with the Persians. He was driven out of Byzantium by Kimoncno. (The date is uncertain, perhaps 476-471—according to Justin he was in possession of Byzantium for seven yearss.)
After he was driven out he went to Kolonai, but was recalled by order of the ephors, imprisoned and again freed through lack of evidence.c

As he sought to overthrow the established order with the help of the helots, the ephors moved energetically against him. He fled to the temple of Athena Chalkioikos for sanctuary, was bricked up and died of starvationckrtu.
The date of his death is uncertain.

person.name: Παυσανίας
person.note: Poralla 596; Thucydides III 26; Pausanias III 5.6-7; Diodorus XIII 75, 107, XIV 17, 89; Xenophon Hellenica II 2.7ff., 4.29-39, III 5.6-7.,17-25, V 2.6; Plutarch Lysander 21, 28-9; Aristotle Athenaion Politeia p. 38; Politica VII 1301b20, 1333b34, 1301b20, 1307a4; Strabo VIII 366; IG V 1. 1564; Nepos Thrasybulus 3; IDelos 87; PW XVIII 2.2578-2584 (Schaefer)
King from the house of the Agids
Father of Agesipolis I and Kleombrotos
During the exile of his father 445-426 he became king.
As he was then a minor his uncle Kleomenes was regent. After the death of Pleistoanax in 408/7 Pausanias became king in fact.
In 405 and 403 we find him with an army in Attica.
In 395 Pausanias campaigned against Thebes, but delayed until after the battle of Haliartos and was for that reason condemned to death. He fled to Tegea where he died of disease.
His death can only have occurred after 385/4 since he was still alive when Agesipolis led a campaign against Mantinea.
In exile he wrote an essay on the reform of the Lycurgan constitution.

person.name: Παυσανίας
person.note: Poralla 597; Suidas s. v.; Aelian varia historia xii 61
Lacedaemonian historian of unknown time, possibly to be identified with P., the son of Pleistoanax (above, but FGrH 592 places him in the time of the Roman empire)

person.name: Παυσανίας (1)
person.note: Gerousias in the year of A.... (5)

person.name: Παύσιππος
person.note: Poralla 598; Arrian Anabasis III 24.4; Curtius Rufus III 13.15; PW XVIII 2.2584-2585 (Schaefer)
A Spartiate who in 330 was an ambassador at the Persian court and after the death of Darius III was taken prisoner by Alexander

person.name: Πεδάριτος
person.note: Poralla 599; Suidas s. v. Πειδάριτος; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.) 231ab, (Lacaenarum apophthegmata incerta 11) 241de; Thucydides VIII 28, 32-33, 38, 40, 55; Harpocratian s. v.; Hellenica Oxyrhynchus 2.1
He appears to be identical with Paidaritos or Paidaretos, the harmost of Chios
He commanded as harmost in 411 in Chios and fell in battle against the Athenians there.

person.name: Πεδέστρατος
person.note: Proxenos, himself and his descendants, of Gortyn

person.name: Πελλῆς
person.note: A Spartiate, one of the friends of Gylis the polemarch
He fell together with Gylis in 394 in Locris.

person.name: Πέλοψ (1)
person.note: He was a socius et amicus of Rome.b
Nabis was supposed to have murdered him.a

person.name: Πέλοψ (2)
person.note: Lacedaemonian proxenos, himself and his descendants, of Geronthrae with rights of property, domicile, and the other customary privileges

person.name: Περικλῆς (1)
person.note: Ephor in the year of Spartiatikos (5), AD 84/5

person.name: Κλαύδιος Περικλῆς (3)

person.name: .... Περικλῆς (7)

person.name: Περικλείδας
person.note: Poralla 608; Thucydides IV 119; Plutarch Cimon 16; Aristophanes Lysistrata 1138ff
He came to Athens as ambassador around 464 to seek help for the Third Messenian War

person.name: Πέρκαλον
person.note: Poralla 609 (9, see F. Bechtel, Die Historische Personennamen des Griechischen, Halle, 1917, p. 234, third name); Herodotus VI 65
She was engaged to Leotychidas, but the later king Damaratos seduced her from her fiancé and married her. Perkalos appears to come from the family of the wise Chilon.

person.name: Περκλῆς
person.note: Name in a catalogue from Oetylus

person.name: Πεύκετος
person.note: J. Baillet, Inscriptions grecques et latines des tombeaux des rois ou Syringes à Thébes (Memoires de l’institut Fr. d’Archéol. Orientale 42, 1920-26), 216 (i. e. 9)

On the question whether P. was officially nauarch of the year 395/4, cf. Ceirikravth"

person.name: Πλάκων

person.name: Πλείσταρχος
person.note: Poralla 611; Herodotus VIII 71, IX 10; Thucydides I 132; Diodorus XIII 75; Pausanias III 5.1
King from the house of the Agids
Son of the king Leonidas and Gorgo
As he was still a minor when his father died, his uncle Kleombrotos became regent and after his death in 479 his cousin Pausanias.
He died in 458 shortly after he came of age.

person.name: Πλειστίας
person.note: A Laconian who, according to an inscription found in Euboea of the fifth century, was raised in Athens and died in Eretria

person.name: Πλειστόαναξ
person.note: King from the house of the Agids
Father of the later king Pausanias
In 458 he succeeded Pleistarchos on the throne. As he was still a minor his uncle became regent.

In Summer 446 he invaded Attica to ravage the land, but turned back to Sparta without an attempt on Athens. His motives were suspected, he was put on trial, and condemned to death. He fled to Lykaion where he lived for 19 years in exile. The kingship passed to his son Pausanias.
He was recalled in 426 and restored to the kingship.
In 420 and 418 we find him fighting in Arcadia.
He died in 408/7 after a fifty year reign.

person.name: Πλειστόλας
person.note: Poralla 614; Thucydides V 19, 24; Xenophon Hellenica II 3.10
In this office he signed the peace and alliance with Athens.

person.name: (Τιβέριος Κλαύδιος) Πλειστόξενος
person.note: Son of Ti. Claudius Harmoneikos (2a)a, a member of the Cynosurian obe
Sysseitos [in the year of Kleandros (5)]a, AD 99/100

person.name: Πλώτιος

person.name: (Τίτος Τρεβελληνός [?]) Πολέμαρχος
person.note: Father of T. Trebellenus Areus (4) and [T.] Trebellenus Philostratos (4)

person.name: Πολιάδης
person.note: Father of the Spartiate Amompharetos who fell at Thermopylae in 480

person.name: Γν(αῖος) Κανίνιος Πολλίας (1)
person.note: Gerousias for the first time in the year of Perikles (3), AD 105/6
Bidyos in the year of Damonikidas (6), AD 109/10
Gerousias for the second time in the year of Polyeuktos (5), AD 110/1
Presbys of gerontes in the year of Hadrian, AD 126/7

person.name: Πόλλης
person.note: Poralla 620; Plutarch Moralia (mulierum virtutes 8) 247d, (quaestiones Graecae 21) 296b-d; Photius Bibliotheca 137b 21, 141a 7
According to legend he was supposed to have led the Tyrrhenians to Crete with Krataidas and Delphos.

person.name: Πόλλις
person.note: Poralla 621; Hellenica Oxyrhynchus 9.2, 19.2; Xenophon Hellenica IV 8.11, V 4.59-61; Polyaenus III 11.11; Plutarch Dion 5, Phocion 6, Camillus 19; Diogenes Laertius III 19; Diodorus XV 34
In 393/92 he was epistoleus of the nauarch Podanemos and was wounded in the Gulf of Corinth.
Around 388 he spent time as ambassador in Syracuse, brought Plato the philosopher back in captivity and put him up for sale as a slave in Aegina.
As nauarch of the year 377/76 P. was defeated by Chabrias at Naxos.

person.name: Πόλλις
person.note: Gravemarker with a relief of a man and woman standing

person.name: Πολυαινίδας
person.note: He is probably one and the same person as the Polyainidas mentioned in Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v. Λόχαγος) 225e, as the son of Lochagos and brother of Seiron.

person.name: Πολυαινείδας (1)
person.note: Ag[oran]omos in the year of Theoxenos (3)

person.name: Πολυαλκῆς
person.note: He was an ambassador in Athens before the outbreak of the Peloponnesian War in 431.

person.name: Πολυά{ν}θης
person.note: IG V 1. 678 (9, but see SEG XI 842f, addenda et corrigenda)
Anonymus [kasen?] to him [in the year of] Aristodami[das]

person.name: Πολυβιάδης

person.name: Πολυβιάδης
person.note: Poralla 625; Xenophon Hellenica V 3.8, 20, 26; Diodorus XV 23.2-3
After the death of Agesipolis in 380 was sent to Chalcidice as his successor and in 379 forced Olynthus to give up.
As he commanded Spartiates, so must he have been a Spartiate.
On the basis of the name we may conclude that he was the son of Naukleides and the grandson of Polybiades (above).

person.name: Πολύβιος (2)
person.note: Eph(or) in the year of Cl(audius) Brasidas (2), AD 164/5

person.name: Τίτος Φλάβιος Πολύβιος (3)
person.note: Honored by Messenia with the boule of Olympia concurring; aristopoliteutes by law in the 259th Olympiad <AD 257>; honored by the Achaean League with the boule of Olympia concurring for his advice and favor in the strategeia of Julius Agrippa

person.name: Πολυδάμας (2)
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristokratidas (1)

person.name: Πολυδαμίδας
person.note: A Lacedaemonian who was a subordinate commander of Brasidas in 423 in Chalcidice

person.name: Πολυδέκτης
person.note: Poralla 627; Pausanias II 36.4; Plutarch Lycurgus 1; Herodotus VIII 131; Justin III 2.5
King from the house of the Eurypontids
The Lycurgus myth, which led to the inclusion of Eunomos in the kings list made P. sometimes the father, sometimes the son of Eunomos.

person.name: Πολύδωρος
person.note: Poralla 628; Herodotus VII 204; Pausanias III 3.1-4, 11.10, IV 7.7; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.) 231def, Lycurgus 8
King from the house of the Agids
He reigned contemporaneously with Theopompos during the first Messenian War and was supposed to have been slain by Polemarchos.
The war of Argos and Sparta over Thyrea is also placed in his reign.
P. also played an important role in the development of the Spartan system. According to Pausanias the ephors kept his portrait in their official residence.

person.name: Πολύ[ε]υκτος (4)
person.note: Gravemarker with a relief of a youth in a toga

person.name: Γά(ιος) Ἰούλιος Πολύευκτος (7)
person.note: Rizakis 499 (suggests identification of some of the different Polyeuktos’s);
Father of Julia —c and C. Julius Seimedes (2)b
Father-in-law of Ti. Claudius Damokrates (2)c and Memmia
Grandfather of Claudia Neikion (1)c (and Ti. Claudius Polyeuktos <8>a)

person.name: Πολυκλῆς
person.note: With the nickname Πολύχαλκος he won with his horses in Olympia and
at the Pythian, Isthmian and Nemean games. He had a statue in Olympia
that represented him with his two little sons.

person.name: Πολυκλῆς (1)
person.note: Epimel[e]tes in the year of Damares (6)

person.name: Πολυκλῆς (2)
person.note: Ephor in the year of C. Julius Kleandros (5), AD 99/100

person.name: Πολυκλῆς (3)
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristomachos (3)

person.name: Πολυκλείδας
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristomachos (3)

person.name: [Αὐρ(ήλιος)? Π]ολυκράτης (2)
person.note: Kibyrates b[ouleutes pe]ntathlos and Philadelpheu[s boule]utes
Xystarches for life of the greater contests Deion A[leion] Philadelpheion and Lacedaemonian bouleutes and Athenian and Ephesian and Nikopolites and a citizen of many other poleis

person.name: Πολυκρατίδας
person.note: He was ambassador to the field commander of the Great King in an unknown time; when asked if he was representing Sparta or himself, he replied, if successful the state, if not, himself. (cf. 9, same story: Plutarch Lycurgus 25.7)

person.name: Πολυνίκης
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristomachos (3)

person.name: Πολύνικος
person.note: In 400/399 he was sent to the Cyrus survivors in Thrace to enlist them for the war against Persia.

person.name: Πολύνικος (1)
person.note: Name on a bronze band in the precinct of Apollo Hyperteleatas

person.name: Πολύνικος (2)
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristomachos (3)

person.name: [Πολ]ύξενος (1)
person.note: Lacedaemo[nian pro]xenos of Gero[nthrae] for his services

person.name: Πολύξενος (2) ΠΙΣΒ
person.note: Ephor in the year of Attic[us]a, AD 133/4; grammateus boulasb

person.name: Πολυπείθης
person.note: Victor of the Olympic games in the four–horse chariot race

person.name: Πολυπείθης
person.note: A Lacedaemonian prostates of the naopoioi at Delphi in the time of the archon Theucharis, 355/4 BC

person.name: Πολυστρατίδας
person.note: He was ambassador to the field commander of the Great King in an unknown time; when asked if he was representing Sparta or himself, he replied, if successful the state, if not, himself. (cf. 9, same story: Plutarch Moralia <apophthegmata Laconica s. v.> 231f)

person.name: Πολύτροπος
person.note: Poralla 633; Diodorus XV 62.1-2; Xenophon Hellenica VI 5.11
Engaged Orchomenos at the head of a Lacedaemonian mercenary army in 369 and fell in a struggle against Lykomedes

person.name: Πολυφόντας
person.note: One of the leaders of the pro-Macedonian faction in Sparta who fled to Philip V in 220 BC to avoid being murdered by members of the pro-Aetolian faction

person.name: Πολύχαρμος
person.note: Hipparch in the army of Teleutias before Olynthos in 382

person.name: Ποσίδιππος
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristomachos (3)

person.name: Ποσειδώνιος
person.note: He fell in 479 at Plataea before he was thirty years old

person.name: Ποσειδώνιος
person.note: Grandfather of Aur(elia) Damokratia (2) and Aur(elia) Onasiphoris

person.name: Αὐρ(ήλιος) Ποτάμων
person.note: Synarch of the gynaikonomia in the year of Sex. Pom(peius) Theoxenos (4)

person.name: Πράξανδρος
person.note: Poralla 636; Strabo XIV 682; Tzetzes ad Lycophron 586
Was supposed to have wandered to Cyprus and there founded Lapathos

person.name: Πραξίας
person.note: Victor in the chariot race of the Roman games held at Oropus to celebrate Sulla's victory, ca. 85 BC

person.name: [Π]ραξίβιος
person.note: An inscription of the fifth century found in Geronthrai

person.name: ΓΑ Πραξιμένης
person.note: Rizakis 205; IG V 1. 96 {9 = Γά(ιος) or Γα(βίννιος)?}
[Gerousias or member of the Taenarian cult]

person.name: Πραξῖνος
person.note: Name on two reliefs, one of a ship with sail set, the other of a woman

person.name: Πραξίτας
person.note: Polemarch of a mora stationed in Sicyon in 393

person.name: Λο(ύκιος) Ἀπρώνιος Πρασιμένης (1)
person.note: (The name “should be” spelled Πραξιμένης. The Ξ could have been
miscut or, on the other hand, who are we to tell the Spartans how to spell
Gerousias in the year of C. Ju(lius) Agesilaos (4), AD 90/1-95/6

person.name: Πράσων
person.note: Grunauer, p. 53 (emission mark 28 sigla 28 ), Gruppe XVII (43-31 BC), Serie 16, Tafel 13, Gruppe XXII (35-31 BC), Serie 4, Tafel 18 (PRA on obverse) suggests that the name should be Prasion (q.v.)
Name on a coin—perhaps the mint official but more likely the holder of an office, gerousias, ephor, or eponymous patronomos

person.name: Μᾶρκος [Α]ὐρήλιος [Πρ]ατέας (1)
person.note: Victor of the [k]asseratoris in the year of M. Aure[li]us Euporos (4)

person.name: Πρατέας (2)
person.note: Gravemarker with relief of a man, clothed in a chiton and pallium, and carrying a sword and spear (i.e, for the Parthian campaigns?)

person.name: Πρατιάδας
person.note: Victor of the boys' keteuon in the eubalkes and kynaget[as]

person.name: Πρατίων (1)
person.note: Damosios skanothekas in the year of Kallikrates (33)

person.name: Πρατόδαμος
person.note: He travelled in 430 as ambassador to Persia but was captured in Thrace by Sadokos, handed over to Athens and there executed.

person.name: Πρατόλας (1)
person.note: IG V 1. 519 (joined to 582, cf. SEG XI 811)
Paid for a memorial to his mother

person.name: Πρατόλας (2)
person.note: Gerousias in the year of Serippos (3)a; member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristokratidas (1)f

person.name: Τιβέριος Κλαύδιος Πρατόλαος (3)
person.note: Rizakis 314 (Stemmata I, II, VI); IG V 1. 497a, 498 b, 526c, 589d;
Father of Claudia Damostheneia (3)ad and Ti. Claudius Aelius Pratolaos (11) ho kai Damokratidasa
Grandfather of Ti. Claudius Pratolaos (10) [ho] kai Damokratidasd
He paid for a memorial to a friend, M. Aur(elius) Agathos.c
Subject of honorary decrees for counseling well and for the execution "with irreproachable attention to duty and generosity in the liturgy" of the office of agoranomos of the roadsa

person.name: Πόπ(λιος) Μέμ(μιος) Πρατόλαος (4) ὁ καὶ Ἀριστοκλῆς
person.note: Father of Memmia Longina (2)f and P. Mem(mius) Damares (4)f
Father-in-law of Pompo(nius) Pantha[les] (2) Diogenes Aristeasf
He, his wife, and his son paid for three statues to his son-in-law, Pomponius Panthales Diogenes Aristeasf.
The contestants, the aleiptai, and those epi ta ethe honored him as the most worthy man for his patronage of the Lycurgan code and for his reverence and honor towards themselvescd.
When he was patronomos he was created epimeletes of the office of the patronomia for the god Lykourgos (1) IVabc

He received that duty the first and only time he was patronomos and he was made epimeletes by the illustrious council and the holy demosc with the concurrence of the illustrious consular corrector Egnatius Proclusb.
His synarchoi honored him when he was patronomose.

person.name: Πρατόλας (5)
person.note: One of hoi sitethentes in the year of Nikok[le]s (7)

person.name: Πόπ(λιος) Μέμ(μιος) Πρατόλας (7)
person.note: Father of Me(mmia) Timosthenis (2)cd (and P. Memmius Deximachos <4>?)
Ephor in the year of Kallikrates (26) Rufiab, AD 151/2

person.name: Π(όπλιος) Μέμμιος Πρατόλαος (8) Δέξστρος
person.note: Rizakis 576; IG V 1. 32Ba, (57, an error for [Πεῖ]ος <2>), 58 (—λάου
Grandfather of P. Memmius Mnason (1) and P. Memmius Pratolaos (9)f
He, together with Volusena Olympicha (2), priestess of the Dioscuri, dedicated a gift of felt to the Dioscuri from their own resources.e
[Philocae]sar; [gerousias]h; presbys of ephors in the year of C. Julius [Agatho]kles (23)g, AD 165/6 or later

person.name: (Πόπλιος) Μέμμιος Πρατόλαος (9)
person.note: Raised a memorial to his father

person.name: Τιβ(έριος) Κλαύ(διος) Πρατόλαος (10) [ὁ] καὶ Δαμοκρατίδας
person.note: Rizakis 315 (Stemmata I, II, VI); IG V 1. 589
Son of (Ti. Claudius) Euda[mos] (18) and Clau(dia) Damostheneia (3)
(Nephew of Ti. Claudius Aelius Pratolaos <11> ho kai Damokratidas)
Paid for a memorial to his mother, Clau(dia) Damostheneia

person.name: Τιβέριος Κλαύδιος Αἴλιος Πρατόλαος (11) ὁ καὶ Δαμοκρατίδας
person.note: Grandson of Brasidas (2)a and Pompeia Polla (2)b

He was, because of his descent, the priest of Karneios Boiketas, Karneios Dromaios, Poseidon Domateitos, Herakles Genarches, Kore, Temenios, the gods in Helos and the associated gods in the aforementioned temples.a
He and his sister paid for a memorial to their fathera and grandmotherb

person.name: Τι(βέριος) Κ[λ(αύδιος) Πρα]τομηλίδας
person.note: “Also with them (i.e., the other synarchoi)” in a time of shortages
Career: Tamias in the year of Per[ikles]
Ag(ora)n[omos] in the year of Pratoneikos
Epimeletes po(leos) [in the year of Neikip]pidas
Priest in the year of Anonymus
[Nomophylax?] in the year of Pasikrates (last office in career)

person.name: Πρατομηλίδας (2)
person.note: A. M. Woodward, BSA XXVI (1925) 168, C6, C7

person.name: Πρατόνικος
person.note: Poralla 640; FDelph III 5. 48 I 21; 50 II 31 (Π…όνικο.); [57 B 15; 58, 26-27; 92 A 26 (--όνικος)
One of the Delphian officials of the naopoioi under the archon Damochares in 338/37

person.name: Πρατόνικος (2)
person.note: Synarch of the epimeletes in the year of Soixiadas (2)

person.name: Πρατόνικος (3)
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristomachos (3)

person.name: Πρατόνικος (4)
person.note: Gerousias in the year of A.... (5)

person.name: Π[ρ]ατόνεικος (5)
person.note: Name in a catalogue [of gerontes]a; [presbys of nom]ophylakes in the year of C. Ju(lius) Charix[enos] (7)b, AD 90/1-92/3

person.name: Πρατόνικος (6)
person.note: Herald of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristomachos (3)c

person.name: Πρατόνεικος (7)
person.note: Nomophylax [in the year of Menekles, AD 96/7]

person.name: Πρατόνεικος (8)
person.note: Father of an unspecified number of children

person.name: Πρατόνικος (9)
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristokratidas (1)

person.name: Πρατό<υ>νικο{ς} (10)
person.note: Nomophylax in the year of [L]ysi[ppos] (3), AD 126/7 or 127/8

person.name: Πρατόνικος (11)
person.note: Chanter of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristomachos (3)b
Gerousias in the year of Serippos (3)a

person.name: Πρατόνικος (13)
person.note: Presbys of bideoi in the year of Lysimachos (1), AD 102/3

person.name: Πρατόνεικος (14)
person.note: Ephor in the year of C. Julius Kleandros (5), AD 99/100

person.name: Πρατόνικος (15)
person.note: Sphaireus in the year of Agathokles (9) Kleophantou, ca. AD 70-80

person.name: Πρατόνικος (16)
person.note: (Poralla 640); FDelph III 5. 48I line 21, 50II line 31, 57B line 15, 58 lines 26/7, 92A line 26

person.name: Πρατόνικος (17)
person.note: Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristomachos (3)

person.name: Πρατόνικος (18)
person.note: Klostas in the year of Nikok[le]s (7)

person.name: Πρατόνικος (25)
person.note: IG V 1. 46 (cf. SEG XI 487); SEG XI 530

person.name: [Πρα]τύλος (1)
person.note: IG V 1. 46 (cf. SEG XI 487)a; SEG XI 530b
[Ger]ousias in the year of Julius [Pa]nthales (3)a, AD 162/3
P[resbys] of eph(ors) in the year of Cl(audius) Brasidas (2)ab, AD 164/5
[N]o(mophylax—presbys?) in the year of Ju(lius) Agatho[kl]es (23)a, AD 165/6 or later
Gramma[te]us boulas in the year of M. Aristokra[te]s (13) Firmia, AD 166/7 or later

person.name: Αὐρ(ήλιος) Πρατύλο[ς] (2)
person.note: Rizakis 178 (AD 212 or later); IG V 1. 684 (cf. SEG XI 844b, addenda

person.name: Πρευκλητία
person.note: IG V 1. 116; SEG XI 590 ("a highly improbable name"); SEG LV
(2005) 474 (reports the suggestion of a verbal adjective πρ<ο>ευκλη-

person.name: Πριανθίς
person.note: Dedicatory inscription from the archaic period on a brass cup

person.name: Πρῖμος
person.note: Victor of the moa in the year of S«i»osinikos (5)
Victor of the kelea in the year of Eudamos (23)

person.name: Πρινητάδας
person.note: Father of the second wife of king Anaxandridas
Through his brother Chilon he was also related (through marriage) with the other royal house
He probably belonged to the noble house of the wise Chilon.

person.name: Προάγορος
person.note: Statue base: " . . . of all Greece. I am Proagoros, son of Diaios of good blood, who won the crown three times from my rivals. Megalopolis bore me, Sparta nursed me—my two fatherlands—glorious virtue for me."

person.name: Πρόθοος
person.note: Poralla 643; Xenophon Hellenica VI 4.2; Plutarch Agesilaus 28
A Spartiate who in 371 probably in his office as ephor delayed the recall of Kleombrotos from Phocis

person.name: Προκλῆς
person.note: Poralla 644; Herodotus IV 147, VI 52, VIII 131; Plutarch Lycurgus 1; Pausanias IV 3.4; Nepos Agesilaus 1; Athenaeus XI 463b
Father of Eurypon (who gave his name to the Eurypontid royal family)
According to another genealogy (Plutarch), he was the father of Soos and grandfather of Eurypon.
As Prokles was not of age at the beginning of his reign Theras was supposed to have been regent for him.

person.name: Προκλῆς
person.note: Poralla 645; Xenophon Hellenica III 1.6; Anabasis II 1.3, VII 8.17
Descendant, perhaps great grandson of the deposed king Damaratos
With his brother Eurysthenes he ruled over Pergamum, Teuthrania, and Halisarna in 400/399.

person.name: Προκλῆς
person.note: Poralla 646; Sextus Empiricus adversus mathematicos I 258
Husband of Pythias, the daughter of the philosopher Aristotle
Father (with her) of two sons, Prokles and Damaratos

person.name: Προκλῆς
person.note: Poralla 647; Sextus Empiricus adversus mathematicos I 258

person.name: Γά(ιος) Ἰούλιος Πρόκλος
person.note: Gerousias in the year of Biadas, AD 153/4, {and Sejanus}

person.name: Προλύτα
person.note: Poralla 648; Plutarch Agesilaus 19; Xenophon Hellenica VII 4.23
Daughter of Agesilaos II and Kleora
Wife, or sister in law, of Chilon

person.name: Πρόμαχος
person.note: Father of Plangon (who died shortly after 347 BC)

person.name: Πρυαῖος
person.note: Witness in a dedicatory inscription from Taenarum of the Epirote Aischrion in the time of the ephor Hagesistratos, 427/6

person.name: Πρύτανις
person.note: King from the house of the Eurypontids
In the Lycurgan tradition he became the father also of Eunomos.

person.name: Πυθαγόρας
person.note: Poralla 651; Olymp 18; Africanus in Eusebius I 196; Dionysius Halicarnassus II 58; Plutarch Numa 1
Victor of the stadion in Ol 16 = 716 at the Olympic games
He is supposed to have advised the Roman king Numa in his lawgiving (which is an attempt to make sense of the story that the philosopher Pythagoras advised king Numa).

person.name: Πυθαγόρας
person.note: Probably a pseudonym for Samios, the nauarch of the year 402/1, cf. Samios (Poralla 659)

person.name: Πυθαγόρας
person.note: Brother of Apia {Apega}, the wife of Nabisa
He commanded the garrison in Argos, 195 BC, until he was forced to withdraw under pressure from the Romansabd.
During an assault on Sparta by the Roman army, he commanded the Lacedaemonian troops and repulsed the assaulte.
He acted as envoy between Nabis and the Roman commander, Flamininuscf.
He commanded Lacedaemonian troops against Philopoemen, general of the Achaean League, 192 BCg
Nothing is known of him after 192 BC (the year of Nabis' death).

person.name: [Πυ]θάνγελος
person.note: Nomophylax in the year of Me(mmius) [Longinus (1)?]

person.name: Πύρριχος
person.note: The mythical creator of the Laconian weapons’ dance, the Pyrrhiche

person.name: Πύρρος (1)
person.note: Rizakis 709; IG V 1. 503a, 504b { = Π(όπλιος) Οὔ(λπιος) or Γ(άιος)
High priest of the emperor and his divine ancestorsab
He paid for a memorial to Ti. Cl(audius) Montanus ho kai Hesychiosb

person.name: Κλα(υδία) Πώλλα (1)
person.note: Rizakis 228 (MID III AD – Stemmata I, VI, X, XI); IG V 1. 602
Paid for a memorial to her daughter

person.name: Πομπηία Πώλλα (2)
person.note: Rizakis 613 (distinguishes the “Polla” of 464 from the “Polla” of 587);
Sister of Sex. Pompeius Theoxenos (5) and Menophanesa
Grandmother of Ti. Claudius Aelius Pratolaos (11) ho kai Damokratidas and Claudia Damostheneia (3)b
Archeis and theoros for life of the holiest contest of the Hyakinthiansb
Subject of an honorary decree for her moderation and piety and other womanly virtuesb

person.name: Πωλλίων (1)
person.note: P[resbys] of ephors in the year of Attic[us], AD 133/4a

person.name: Πωλλίων (2)
person.note: Rizakis 612; IG V 1. 97 (cf. SEG XI 564b)a; SEG XI 510b, 535c,
Ephor in the year of Spartiatikos (5)b
G(rammateus) b(oulas) in the year of C. Ju(lius) Philoklidas (3)ad, AD 91/2- 95/6

person.name: Ραμφίας
person.note: Poralla 654; Thucydides I 139a, V 12-13b, VIII 8c; Xenophon Hellenica I 1.35d
He was ambassador to Athens in 431 before the outbreak of the
Peloponnesian Wara. In summer 422 he led an army into Thessalyb.

person.name: L(ucius) Aemilius Quir(ina) Rectus
person.note: CIL 3423, 3424, 5941 (supplement); Prosopographia Imperii Romani saec. I II III, ed. E. Groag and Stein, Berlin, 1932-, A 394/395
Citizen of Carthage, Sparta, and other cities

person.name: Μεμ(μιος) Ρητορικός
person.note: Synarchos in a list of magistrates

person.name: Ριψόλαος
person.note: Poralla 655; Africanus in Eusebius I 200; Olymp 65
Olympic victor in the stadion, 39th Ol = 624

person.name: Ρούβρ[ιος]
person.note: [Subject <?> of an honorary decree — for courage]

person.name: Τιβέριος Kλ(αύδιος) Ρουφεῖνος
person.note: Rizakis 318; SEG XI 806a, addenda et corrigenda
A close friend of M. Aurelius Epiteuktikos (2)
He was the subject of an honorary decree of Amyclae as hieronikes and irreproachable agoranomos

person.name: Ρο[ῦφ]ος (1)
person.note: Eph(or) in the year of Cl(audius) Brasidas (2), AD 164/5

person.name: M(ᾶρκος) Αὐρ(ήλιος) Ρο[ῦφος] (2)
person.note: Rizakis 179 (Son of Kleanor)/179a; IG V 1. 683a; unpublished

Bideos in the fifth year of the god Lykou[r]gos (3)a; presbys of
nomophylakes in the year when the city honored Julius Paulinus

person.name: Ροῦφ[ος] (3)
person.note: Rizakis 668; IG V 1. 140 (cf. SEG XI 616a); Bradford Chiron (1980) 417
Father of Aur(elius) Damaristos (3) (or an agnomen = Aur(elius) Damaristos Ruf[us]?)

person.name: Σ— (8)

He and his brother, Teisamenos (1), the sons of Arist[oma]chos (4), the boagoi, received laurel crowns with [Iamos (1)?], who won the keloia

note.hi: That is, he is a member of the famous family of seers. Cf. Σιχάρης

person.name: Γά(ιος) Σ———-
person.note: Gerousias (?) in the year of Anonymus

(Steinhauer suggests that this name might be C. Julius Secundus, but the praenomen is distinguished in two fashions as an abbreviation, by a line over it and enclosed by [<]>. There is no apparent abbreviation, however brief, for Julius and therefore the nomen must be S—.)
Σ—, IG V 1. 61, error for [πρέσβυ]ς, see SEG XI 547a

person.name: Μουνατία Σαβείνα

Raised a memorial to her husband

person.name: Σ[α]κίντα
person.note: Name from the precinct of Apollo, Amyclae, associated with Kallikrates (32)

person.name: Σάλαιθος
person.note: When the city was taken by the side favoring the Athenians he was taken prisoner, brought to Athens, and there executed.

person.name: Σάμιος
person.note: Son of Archias (who fell around 525 before Samos)

person.name: Σάμιος
person.note: Poralla 659; Diodorus XIV 19.4-5 (Σάμος); Xenophon Hellenica III 1.1-2

He was sent by the Spartan regime to help Cyrus. In the Anabasis I 2.21 Xenophon names in place of Samios a "Pythagoras" as nauarch. One may guess, that Xenophon, whose Anabasis was published under a pseudonym, also used a pseudonym here, and a "Samios" lies very near to a "Pythagoras." This Samios appears to be the grandson of the foregoing Samios and the son of Archias, cf. Ἀρχιάς (Poralla 151)

person.name: Σαμίτας
person.note: Σάμος, Poralla 660a; Diodorus XIV 19.4-5, see Σάμιος

person.note: Poralla 664; Thucydides I 85-87, VIII 5; Pausanias 5 III 7, 11
In the war assembly in Sparta in 432 he presented the case for war.
(As this assembly was probably held at the end of August or the beginning of September and as this duty fell to him, we may conclude that he was the eponymous ephor of the year 433/2)

person.name: Σθενέλαος
person.note: Was established as harmost of Byzantium and Calchedon by Lysander after the battle of Aegospotami

person.name: Σθενέλαος
person.note: One of the pro-Macedonian faction in Sparta killed by agents of the pro-Aetolian faction, 220 BC

person.name: Σθένιππος
person.note: Came, apparently at the behest of the ephors, to Tegea and there assassinated the archon Aristokles
Grunauer, p. 53 (emission mark 3 sigla 03 ), Gruppe XIII (48-40 BC), Serie 4, Tafel 8, XIV (48-40 BC), 6-7, T 8, Gruppe XV (48-40 BC), Serie 3-5, Tafel 9 suggests Sidamos or Sidektas
Name on a coin—perhaps the mint official but more likely the holder of an office, gerousias, ephor, or eponymous patronomos

person.name: Κυίντος Αὐφιδηνὸς Σειδέκτας (1)
person.note: A philosopher granted a statue in Sparta
(His nomen would suggest that he was not a native of Sparta, although his cognomen is quite Spartan.)

The line reads Κυίντον Αὐφιδηνὸν Κυίντον Σειδέκτα which leads to several interpretations. I take the second Quintus as a cutter’s error for the gentive and patronymic, thus Q. Aufidenus Seidektas, son of Quintus {Aufidenus}. Woodward takes it to mean that we have here a Q. Aufidenus who is the son of Q. {Aufidenus} Seidektas. Cartledge and Spawforth read the name as Q. Aufidenus Quintus, son of Seidektas, affirm that he is Spartan, and date him to the early Severan period (AD 193-211).

A Spartiate, who in 395 acted as military adviser and commander of the neodamodeis in the army of Agesilaos in Asia Minor. On the return he was taken prisoner by the Thessalians in Larissa but was freed by Agesilaos.

He was high priest of the emperors for the Achaean Leaguec
He was granted the equus publicus by Claudius.e
He was tribunus militum and procurator of Nero and Agrippina (before AD 55).e

Was in 378 established as harmost in Thespiai and undertook from here an attempt on Athens which misfired. He escaped condemnation through the influence of Agesilaos II. He fell at the battle of Leuctra.

person.name: Τελευτία
person.note: This "Paidaretos" may be identified with the Pedaritos who fell at Chios in 411.
If so, then this Teleutia is the wife of Leon and mother of Antalkidas.

person.name: Τελευτία
person.note: Poralla 689; Diodorus XV 21a; Plutarch Agesilaus 21b; Thucydides VIII 6c; Xenophon Hellenica IV 4.19d, 8.11e, 8.23-25f, V 1.13-24g, 2.37-3.6h

Stepbrother of King Agesilaos II and Kyniska, probably from a marriage, after the death of Archidamos II, between Eupolia and Theodorosbd. Around 392 Teleutias together with Agesilaos destroyed the wall of Lechaiond. Afterwards he was occupied in the sea war. Did he hold three nauarchies? According to Xenophone Teleutias came to the fleet, which Herippidas (after the nauarch Podanemos was killed) took over and most likely T. was appointed then as nauarch. Then sometime in 390 Teleutias took over the fleet of the nauarch Ekdikos, was then for a long time busy in Rhodes and turned past Aigina back homef. In both cases we see that Teleutias entered into the position of nauarch and occupied it for a long time. Since there was no other sea campaign we must either conclude that Teleutias was nauarch or that the nauarch did not command the fleet in the area of operations (which by Lacedaemonian custom is certainly possiblec). During his third nauarchy Teleutias was harassed at Aigina from Athensg. In summer 382 he marched to Chalkidike, where in spring 381 he was defeated and killed by the Olynthiansah.

person.name: Τισαμενός (1)
person.note: Poralla 703; Herodotus IX 33-36; Pausanias III 11.5-9; Plutarch Aristides 11
From the family of the Klytiads and the clan of the Iamids.

He was a famous seer and for that reason was granted full citizenship, along with his brother, by the Spartans. He is first mentioned at the battle of Plataea (479) and last at the battle of Tanagra (457).
His family continued in Elis down to the time of Agis IV (VIII 10.5ff, VI 2.4-5)

person.name: Τισαμενός (2)
person.note: Poralla 704; Xenophon Hellenica III 3.11a; Pausanias III 11.5-6b
A soothsayer, who was involved in the conspiracy of Cinadona.
He is a descendant of the Iamid family given Spartan citizenship (perhaps the brother of Agias, seer at the battle of Aegospotami)b.

person.name: Τύννιχος
Τυρταῖος
person.note: Poralla 709; Athenaeus XIV 630f a; Diodorus XV 66.3b; Pausanias IV 15.6c; Plato Laws I 188-191d; Stephanus Byzantius s. v. 9e; Strabo VIII 362f; Suidas s. v. 9g; Tirteo, ed. Carlo Prato, Rome, 1968 (fragments and testimonia collected). Prato testimonia (with Prato's abbreviations) not found in Poralla: Aelian de natura animalium VI 1, varia historia XII 50; L. Ampelius Liber memorialis 14 (p. 27 Assmann); Aristides Orationes XXXIII 425 (I p. 639 Dind.); Aristotle Politica V 1306b; Dio Chrysostum Orationes II 29, XXXVI 10; Diodorus VIII 27. 1-2; Diogenes Laertius II 43 (I p. 74f Long); Eusebius Praep. ev. V 28, I p. 274, 15ff Mras ( = Oenom. fr. 10 Mull.); Eustathius in Il. III 76, p. 386, 1ff; Galen de Hippoc. et Plat. plac. III 4 p. 281 Mue.; Harpocration Lexicon s. v. (p. 295 Dind.); Hieronymus Chron. 96b, 17 ad annum 633, 96b Helm; Horace ars poetica 401f; Insc. Acarn. saec. III-II a. Chr., ed. Klaafenbach, Sitzungber. Preuss. Akad., 1935, pp. 718f; Joannis Sicel. Doxop. Comm. in Hermog. περὶ ἰδεῶν (VI p. 139 Walz); Justin III 5, 4-15; Lycurgus In Leocratem 106f, Maxim. Tyr. XXXVII 5 (p. 432, 15 Hob.); Orosius Adv. pag. I 21, 7 (p. 32 Zang.); Pausanias IV 15.2, 16.2, 16.6, 18.2; Philod. de mus. 28 Kemke (XI 89, fr. 16); Plato Laws I 629a-e, 630c, II 666e-667a, IX 858e; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica ) 230d, 235f, Cleomenes II 3, pro nob. 2 (Mor. VII p. 200 Bern.), terra an aqua anim. sint callidiora 959a; Pollux IV 107 (p. 233 Bethe); Polyaen. Strat. I 17; Porphyrio ad Hor. art. poet. 402 (p. 176 Holder); Procl. in Plat. Remp. comm. 402 (p. 186f Kroll); Ps. Acro ad Hor. art. poet. 402; Quintilian X 1, 56, XII 11, 27 Raderm.; Strabo VIII 5,6; schol. in Aristot. Eth. Nic. III 11, 1116b; Schol. in Dionys. Thrac. Art. gramm. p. 168, 8 Hilgard; Schol. T in Hom. Il. XV 496 (II p. 138 Maas); Scholia to Plato Laws I 629a, 630a (p. 301 Chase Greene); Tzetz. Chil. 692ff; Themist. Or. XV 197c-198a (p. 284 Downey), 198c (p. 285 Downey)
A Spartiate from the Laconian Aphidna.
Poet of elegies and general of the Spartans in the Second Messenian Warfg.

The tradition reveals a controversy about the nationality of Tyrtaeus. One of the sources of Strabo, however, to which we owe the best information about the Messenian war, and which itself goes back to the poetry of Tyrtaeus, knows Tyrtaeus only as a Spartiate and general. Suidasg found a notice in a source Lavkwn h] Milhvsio". The latter is easily understood. The oldest practising poets in Sparta came from Asia Minor. After the abortive effort of Athens in the Third Messenian War, a tradition was invented that Tyrtaeus was an Athenian, whom the Spartans had asked for as general and poet of war songs. (It should be mentioned that there is also an Athenian locale called Aphidna.)ef We find this tradition first in Platod. It was then spread through those friendly to Athens: Philochorosa, Ephorosb, and Kallisthenesf. The invented epic then took a grotesque form: Tyrtaeus became a lame school mastercg.

person.name: Φάραξ
person.note: A Spartiate who took part in the battle of Mantinea in 418 as an adviser of king Agis IIa. He also participated in the battle at Aegospotamid. As nauarch of the year 398/7 he was occupied in the theater of war in Asia Minorceg. In 396/5 he was with Dionysius of Syracuse and supported him in his war against Carthageb. In summer 390 he found himself at the Isthmus with Agesilaosf.
Cavaignac: the generations are—Pharax 717 (the grandfather, adviser to Agis), Styphon 675 (the son), Pharax 718 (the grandson, nauarch[?], ambassador)

person.name: Φιλοχαρίδας
person.note: Was occupied in negotiating the armistice between Athens and Sparta in 422 and signed the peace of Nicias in the following year. After that he travelled with Klearidas to Thrace and swore to the alliance with Athens after his return in the summer 421. In the next year he went again on a diplomatic mission to Athens.

person.note: Brother of the Spartiate Eudamidas and father of Isadas

In late summer of 382 during his march to Thrace he made a secret agreement with some Thebans and seized the Cadmea. In 378 he was left behind by Agesilaos as harmost in Thespiai and in a struggle against the Thebans met his death.

person.name: Χαρίλας?
person.note: A contemporary of the Lacedaemonian Archidamidas (who lived during the Persian wars), probably also Spartan
He had been praised for being kind to all alike and Archidamidas wondered how a man be praised who was kind to both good and bad alike.

person.name: Χάριλ[λ]ος
person.note: Old dedicatory inscription found in the Cynuria

person.name: Χάριλλος
person.note: Poralla 747; Herodotus VIII 131 (Χαρίλαος); Diodorus VII 8 (Chariclus); Pausanias II 36.4, III 2.5, VIII 5.9; Heraclides Ponticus in Müller, Fragmenta Historicorum Graecorum, Paris, 1878, II p. 210; Plutarch Cleomenes 10, Lycurgus 1. 3. 5; Sosibius fr 2 in Müller FHG II 625; Justin III 2.5
King from the house of the Eurypontids
After one version of the Lycurgus story he is supposed to be the son of the invented (and inserted) king Eunomos, but this may be rejected as an attempt to link him with Lycurgus.
Pausanias allows that he took Aigys with Archelaos and later marched against Tegea where he was taken prisoner, though soon freed.
The ancient chronographers gave him a reign of 60 or 64 years.

person.name: Χίλων
person.note: He was the father of a daughter, the Pythagorean Chilonis, and a son, Damagetos, whose name is not given but deduced. Chilon was considered in antiquity as one of the seven wise men and many sayings are attributed to him. He lived in the time of the Pisistratids and was eponymous ephor of the year 556/5. Chilon was supposed to have been the first ephor. In any case he was the author of a reform of the ephoria in some major aspect. He died shortly after his ephoria. His daughter (cf. 9) had probably a second son Damarmenos, whose grandchildren intermarried with the collateral members of the royal houses. Chilon later received divine honors in Sparta.

person.name: Χίλων
person.note: A distinguished Spartan, son of Demarmenos, brother of Prinetadas and father of Perkalos, the wife of king Damaratos

person.name: Χίλων

She accompanied her husband into exile, 241 BC

person.name: Χίονις
person.note: Poralla 765; Joannes of Antioch fr. 27 in Müller, Fragmenta Historicorum Graecorum, Paris, 1878, IV 540 (Χίονος); Pausanias III 14.3, IV 23.4, 10, VIII 39.3; Africanus in Eusebius I 198; Olymp 42-47

A Lacedaemonian who won seven victories at the Olympic games, four times in the stadion and three times in the distance run and so had statues in his honor at Sparta and Olympia. Africanus gives only three stadion victories to Chionis (Ol 29, 30, 31) and names Charmis as victor of the stadion in Ol 28. That must be an error since Pausanias mentions the victories of Chionis several times and consistently lists Ol 28 as his first victory. He was supposed to have accompanied Battos as founder to Cyrene.

person.name: Χίονις
person.note: Ephor of the year 422/1. One of the signers of the Peace of Nicias
Χίονος, Poralla 766a; Ioan. Antioch fr. 27 in Müller, Fragmenta Historicorum Graecorum, Paris, 1878, IV 540, cf. Χίονις

person.name: Χειρικράτης
person.note: The chronology of his office is loaded with difficulties since Pollis was nauarch in 396/95 and Peisandros for 395/4 and so there is no room for Cheirikrates (but the Oxyrhynchus historian writes that he arrived as nauarch and the successor of Pollis). A couple of solutions have been proposed: that Ch. filled out an abbreviated term of Pollis or that Peisandros was appointed to a command by Agesilaus but was not actually nauarch.

person.name: Χειρίσοφος
person.note: A Spartiate from the number of the homoioi. In 401 he commanded the forward elements of the detachment of Cyrus' army in agreement with Sparta. After Clearchus was taken prisoner by Tissaphernes Ch. became the commander in chief of the Greek mercenaries. (Xenophon implies that Ch. took part in the expedition of Cyrus at the behest of Sparta. Moreover he allows that Ch took over the high command first in Sinope. Xenophon would not otherwise have related the choice of Cheirisophos to the supreme command, if he had not been forced through the account of the part of the army in Herakleia. Also in various parts of the Anabasis Ch has already exercized the supreme command.) He led the army to Trapezus and betook himself to Byzantium to fetch over ships. His request was rejected by the Spartan nauarch Anaxibios and he returned to the army and died in Kalpe.
